content_item.parsed_text: Subscribe to receive announcements about upcoming events in your city to receive our e-Bulletin (3 times a year) Last Name First Name Company Title E-mail Telephone City Industry - Agriculture Construction and Real Estate Consulting Food Industry Investor Legal Media NGO Production Other Russian Government Services Technology Transport/Logistics U.S. Government University Education Role Manager Entrepreneur Top Manager Instructor Government Employee Expert Student Other Submit Русский Subscribe For announcements of upcoming events and/or our e-Bulletin ﻿ About Programs for Entrepreneurs Youth Entrepreneurship Initiatives Matching Funding Resource Center Entrepreneurship Insights e-Bulletin Videos Press For Donors Partners Contacts ﻿ G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance Meets in Seoul Prior to the G20 Summit November 9, 2010: Seoul, South Korea. Leading organizations representing millions of young entrepreneurs in countries across the G20 signed a charter outlining a framework of how it will engage the G20 process to include entrepreneurship in its ongoing agenda. The G20 Young Entrepreneurs Alliance (YEA) is made up of the leading organizations that support young entrepreneurs around the world. In recognition that entrepreneurship is now, more than ever, at the heart of the new 21st century economy, it has committed to sharing best practice on the entrepreneurial ecosystem within each of its member nations to further enhance competitiveness, growth, job and wealth creation. The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship represents Russia on the G20 YEA. The Alliance’s work in Korea built on its successful launch at the G20 Young Entrepreneurs Summit in Toronto, Canada in June 2010. Members signed the charter and committed to an ongoing process of engagement with the G20 movement (a copy of the charter follows). Through its role as the forum for championing the cause of G20 emerging entrepreneurs, Alliance members will also share experiences, initiatives and policies going forward in building entrepreneurial economies and fostering entrepreneurship in G20 nations and worldwide. "We, Young Entrepreneurs' Society of Korea (YES Korea), are so pleased to be the host of G20 Young Entrepreneurs Summit, Seoul, Korea.” said Michael Lee, CEO of the organization. “All representatives discussed strategies for making the G20 YEA an even more impactful and sustainable global movement." The Alliance will meet prior to each G20 leaders’ summit. The next meeting will be taking place in France in November 2011 and will be hosted by Les Journees de l'Entrepreneur. "We are proud to organize the next G20 Young Entrepreneurs Summit in France,” said Gregoire Sentilhes, Chairman of the organization. “Our ambition is to inspire the future generation of entrepreneurs and foster the hope attached to entrepreneurship as the social and economic link between government and citizens". The G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance The G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance (YEA) is a global network of young entrepreneurs and the organizations that support them. YEA was established to convene each year in advance of the G20 Summit to champion the importance of young entrepreneurs to the G20 member nations and to share our own examples and practices. The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE) is a development organization that promotes economic opportunity, helps build a strong middle class that strengthens civil society and democracy, and enhances the relationship between Russia and the US. CFE identifies and develops entrepreneurs throughout Russia and provides them with the knowledge, skills and personal abilities to start and build growth companies. It enhances a culture of entrepreneurship by raising awareness of entrepreneurship as an engine for economic development and job creation, and expanding the capacity of entrepreneurship support organizations. And, CFE advances entrepreneurship education at the university level to inspire future generations of entrepreneurs. For more information, please contact: Eric Hansen Vice President The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship +7-499-929-7927 www.cfe.ru Incheon Charter of the G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance November 7 – 9 2010, Incheon, South Korea The G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance Meeting, in Incheon, this 9 th day of November 2010, recognizes that young entrepreneurs are powerful drivers of economic renewal, job creation, innovation and social change. We, the Members of the Alliance, recognize the need to bring together organizations from industrialized and developing economies to champion the cause of young entrepreneurs. Building on our engagement at the June 2010 Toronto G20 Summit, we, the Members of the Alliance, commit to a long term engagement of the G20 as an extension of our missions to champion the cause of young entrepreneurs in our respective countries and across the globe. Through our global movement, we believe we can make the 21 st century the Century of the Entrepreneur. We, the Members of the G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance, have set forth the following Charter: WHO WE ARE The G20 Young Entrepreneurs’ Alliance (YEA) is a global network of young entrepreneurs and the organizations that support them. We have been established to convene each year in advance of the G20 Summit to champion the importance of young entrepreneurs to the G20 member nations and to share our own examples and practices. OUR VISION We, the signatories of this Charter, envision: (1) a network that, through its discussions with governments, the media, the public and each other, champions the cause of young entrepreneurs at the local, national and international level. (2) an alliance of organizations from industrialized and developing economies that makes measurable progress towards its goal of a world where an increasing number of entrepreneurs grow businesses, create jobs, change lives and ensure future economic prosperity. (3) a recognized body that exists as part of the official G20 process and is able to engage, contribute to and impact the findings of the G20 to raise awareness and address the issues of emerging entrepreneurs across the globe. OUR BELIEFS We, the signatories of this Charter, believe that: (1) as entrepreneurs found their businesses and change their own lives, they are important contributors to social change, job creation and economic renewal. (2) strengthening the support of entrepreneurs and providing opportunities for international cooperation will help foster economic growth and development across the globe. (3) advocating the cause of emerging entrepreneurs and promoting their importance will prepare the next generation for the renewal and growth of our economies and societies. (4) a recognized alliance of diverse organizations will empower our influence and legitimacy. (5) supporting the dreams of these entrepreneurs is a top priority and should be an increasing priority for the governments of the G20. OUR COMMITMENT TO YOUNG ENTREPRENEURS The signatories of this Charter commit to: (1) supportand encourage young entrepreneurs across the globe. (2) strengthen international cooperation and promote open and constructive discussion on key issues relating to the support and growth of young entrepreneurs. (3) share information and resources among Members for the benefit of young entrepreneurs. (4) engagethe G20 and provide a forum for the discussion of issues found by young entrepreneurs. CHARTER ADOPTED AT THE G20 YOUNG ENTREPRENEURS’ ALLIANCE MEETING, 9 NOVEMBER 2010, INCHEON, SOUTH KOREA November 9, 2010 ← Return to List of Articles © The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 2010 Site Map Development — Webmaster.SPb

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
G20 Young Entrepreneurs Alliance Meets in Seoul

November 9, 2010

G20 Young Entrepreneurs Alliance Convenes in Seoul Prior to G20 Summit

November 9, 2010: Seoul, South Korea. The G20 Young Entrepreneurs Alliance (YEA), a global network of young entrepreneurs and the organizations that support them, met in Seoul to discuss strategies for enhancing the entrepreneurial ecosystem and fostering global entrepreneurship. The Alliance's work in Korea built on its successful launch at the G20 Young Entrepreneurs Summit in Toronto, Canada in June 2010. Leading organizations representing millions of young entrepreneurs signed a charter outlining a framework for ongoing engagement with the G20 process to include entrepreneurship in its agenda.

Key Organizations Driving Global Entrepreneurship

The G20 Young Entrepreneurs Alliance (YEA) was established to champion the importance of young entrepreneurs to the G20 member nations and to share practices that enhance competitiveness and growth. It represents organizations from both industrialized and developing economies, advocating for young entrepreneurs as crucial drivers of economic renewal, job creation, and social change. The Young Entrepreneurs Alliance aims to inspire future generations of entrepreneurs through events, resources, and international cooperation. Meanwhile, the Global Entrepreneurship Week celebrates innovators and job creators who launch startups that bring ideas to life and drive economic growth.
page_cooked.page_title: G20 Young Entrepreneurs Alliance Meets in Seoul
page_cooked.page_description: The G20 Young Entrepreneurs Alliance meets in Seoul to discuss strategies for enhancing entrepreneurial ecosystems and fostering global entrepreneurship.
page_cooked.page_keywords: G20, Young Entrepreneurs Alliance, entrepreneurship, Seoul, global entrepreneurship

The Young Entrepreneurs Alliance aims to inspire future generations of entrepreneurs through events, resources, and international cooperation. Meanwhile, the Global Entrepreneurship Week celebrates innovators and job creators who launch startups that bring ideas to life and drive economic growth.

content_item.parsed_text: Subscribe to receive announcements about upcoming events in your city to receive our e-Bulletin (3 times a year) Last Name First Name Company Title E-mail Telephone City Industry - Agriculture Construction and Real Estate Consulting Food Industry Investor Legal Media NGO Production Other Russian Government Services Technology Transport/Logistics U.S. Government University Education Role Manager Entrepreneur Top Manager Instructor Government Employee Expert Student Other Submit Русский Subscribe For announcements of upcoming events and/or our e-Bulletin ﻿ About Programs for Entrepreneurs Youth Entrepreneurship Initiatives Matching Funding Resource Center Entrepreneurship Insights e-Bulletin Videos Press For Donors Partners Contacts ﻿ Developing into an Entrepreneur Yulia Konstantinova, All About Finance for Small Business magazine by OPORA CREDIT According to a Gallup-Healthways survey, which covered over 100,000 people in the USA in 2009, entrepreneurs and small business owners ranked their level of satisfaction with their work and business environment higher than all other groups of people. Entrepreneurs turned out to be the happiest Americans as perceived by themselves. Victor Sedov , Executive Director of The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, shares his view on the entrepreneurial phenomenon in Russia. Mr. Sedov, does it take to be born an entrepreneur or is it a matter of development? Difficult to say. Some studies result in quite specific findings suggesting that students who read entrepreneurship, among other things, start up a business of their own much more frequently than those without entrepreneurship training. This is an expected result, suggesting that entrepreneurship can and must be taught, the sooner the better, exactly like in any other field. Learning foreign languages, for example, is much easier in childhood. The same is true of mastering skills. Of course, one can be naturally predisposed to entrepreneurship in the same way as to any other activity. The younger generation now has a very good entrepreneurial potential. They don’t have the legacy of the Soviet past which threatened entrepreneurs with criminal prosecution. They are strong, enthusiastic and confident of success. Studies indicate that the desire to start up a business declines dramatically among people older than 25 years of age because they are much more prudent in weighing all the risks of enterprise, they are more skeptical as they realize the complexity of running a business of their own. President Medvedev recently announced that the number of those employed in Russian small businesses should be raised to 70 percent by 2020, whereas it is 10 percent now. In my view, we shall be able to arrive at that figure only if we take the issue of entrepreneurship education seriously and show the younger generation instruments to help them meet their entrepreneurial ambitions. But what do you think is Russia’s main obstacle to starting a business of one’s own: lack of startup capital, administrative barriers, or insufficient information? Serious administrative barriers do exist despite certain measures to reduce them that the government has been undertaking recently. However, the information field is quite broad in these issues. Also, there are opportunities to raise financial resources. So, I would say that it’s a matter of psychology. Is it true that a lot of beginning entrepreneurs avoid credits and prefer borrowing from family members or friends because the Russian mentality prevents them from living on borrowings? Business development using borrowings is a typical and quite usual thing, both in Western countries and in Russia. “Family” money is absolutely sufficient to successfully run a small family business, like a small shop. But when it comes down to business development one has to raise a different scale of funding. The difference is that borrowings are cheap in the West while the credit rates in Russia are very high. Moscow offers beginning entrepreneurs up to 350,000 rubles support grants, on a competition basis subject to certain conditions. Do you think it is much or little? It depends on what and where your business is. For Moscow it may be little, but somewhere in the province it may be enough. It’s not so much a matter of lack of funding, but rather lack of quality projects and original ideas. Last August, A. Sharov (head of Small and Medium Business Support Department, Ministry of Economic Development - editor’s comment ) said that funds for small business support have been allocated, they are available but there are very few people who are eligible for those funds. There are no interesting business ides, so the funds are very likely to stay unexpended. I’m afraid I can’t agree with you. The Internet is full of stories by people who failed to get through the administrative procedures and get grants. I am not saying getting these funds is as easy as it may seem to someone. I also admit that occasionally some things are simply not properly designed administratively. Just one example that everyone is talking about and I have personally faced: re-registration of limited liability companies. The re-registration mess, which arose for lack of distinct explanations from the Federal Tax Authority and poorly engineered procedure, was quite broadly covered in the press. Mr. Sedov, for several years you have been on the jury panel of the Entrepreneur of the Year international competition. This year you chaired the panel, so you are in a position to judge how much Russian entrepreneurs are competitive on the global market? Over the years of the competition, we have seen a rising number of Russian participants and a rising share of small business participants. Last year, for example, there was a separate nomination established for family business. As regards international competitiveness, I must say that the finalists of the national stage include very impressive nominees; suffice it to mention the winners of previous years, like Ruben Vardanyan, President of the Troika Dialog Group, Sergei Vykhodtsev, President of VELLE, and others to realize that people like them are competitive at any level. How important is the “human factor” in determining the winner? Entrepreneur of the Year winners are determined by a national jury composed of previous years’ finalists of the competition, independent experts, prominent businesspeople. I must emphasize, Ernst & Young themselves do not sit on the panel. The criteria of winner selection include both quantitative factors like the growth rate of the company’s turnover, profit and number of jobs, and qualitative aspects like the degree of innovation in the business practices, the development of original products, creative marketing and sale solutions, the scale of national and international presence, implementation of personnel development programs. The winner is selected against a combination of all these factors. The US-Russia Center for Entrepreneurship initiated the setup of the Russian Association of Entrepreneurship Education. What is the purpose of the Association? The Russian Association of Entrepreneurship Education was established in 2008. It is expected to make the best western and Russian experience available to all those who want it. The United States Association for Small Business and Entrepreneurship (USASBE), which has been successful in the USA for 52 now, was taken as an example to follow. Geraldine Franklin, President of USASBE and Dean of the Business College at South Florida University, made a special trip to Moscow to tell her counterparts about the USASBE setup. Under the operation model of the Russian Association of Entrepreneurship Education, leading university professors from Moscow, St. Petersburg and other Russian regions take a course of training abroad to be able to teach entrepreneurship in Russia later. This creates a strong chain: professor training - student training - setup of small businesses by former students. We have seen the first results. For instance, the Economic Department of Moscow State University has set up a Center of Entrepreneurship, and an entrepreneurship training course has been designed in St. Petersburg on the basis of Russian business cases. It is a very important step because a review of US business cases in the Russian environment is not always possible or reasonable, while the above course analyses, among other things, the experience of “the Russian McDonald's”, the ChainayaLozhka chain in St. Petersburg, a leader on the local restaurant and fast food market. Following this model, the Russian Association of Entrepreneurship Education will be able to identify the best Russian curricula and set up higher-level entrepreneurship education standards on that basis. The Russian Association of Entrepreneurship Education includes about 70 members now. And yet, what is it that determines a successful business? Professional qualities alone or luck, a happy chance? To be able to use a chance one has to be prepared for it. Take Oleg Tinkov for example. He launched his credit card project much later than others and seemed hopelessly behind everybody else. But this is precisely what helped him and his project a success. It is a combination of business intuition and an understanding of what the market needs at this specific moment in time. Entrepreneurial skills are like a sail that must be driven by wind - circumstances, chance, luck. But the boat is not going anywhere without the sail. What would you wish for the readers of OporaKredit ? My impression is that in covering entrepreneurship the media tend to focus on negative facts associated with small businesses, like tax dodging for example, rather than quote success stories. From that perspective, I like the Entrepreneur of the Year awards because it inspires and sets a positive example to everyone. This is why I see the OporaKredit project as very useful: it provides important practical information for those involved in small business activities or planning to do so. I wish for OporaKredit readers to be persistent in striving towards their goals and being successful! The international competition, Entrepreneur of the Year, supported by Ernst & Young, has been held in 50 countries of the world for over 20 years . Russia has held the national stage of the competition since 2003 . On November 26, 2009, the Entrepreneur of 2009 award ceremony took place in Moscow ; the winner was Oleg Khusaenov, General Manager of Atlant-M, a holding company . THE U.S. RUSSIA CENTER FOR ENTREPRENEURSHIP 23 1stTverskaya-Yamskaya St., Moscow, 125047, Russia Tel. +7 (499) 929-7927 www.cfe.ru December 1, 2009 ← Return to List of Articles © The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 2010 Site Map Development — Webmaster.SPb

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
Developing Entrepreneurs and Business Satisfaction

December 01, 2009

Insights from the Entrepreneurial World

According to a Gallup-Healthways survey, which covered over 100,000 people in the USA in 2009, entrepreneurs and small business owners ranked their level of satisfaction with their work and business environment higher than all other groups. Entrepreneurs turned out to be the happiest Americans as perceived by themselves. The younger generation has a very good entrepreneurial potential. They don't have the legacy of the past, which threatened entrepreneurs. They are strong, enthusiastic, and confident of success. Studies indicate that the desire to start up a business declines dramatically among people older than 25, because they are much more prudent in weighing all the risks of enterprise, and realize the complexity of running a business. To meet ambitious goals, entrepreneurship education should be taken seriously and the younger generation should be shown instruments to help them in their entrepreneurial ambitions. Entrepreneurial skills are like a sail that must be driven by wind - circumstances, chance, luck. But the boat is not going anywhere without the sail. The international competition, Entrepreneur of the Year, supported by Ernst & Young, has been held in 50 countries for over 20 years. Winners are determined by the unanimous decision of a national jury, including previous winners, independent experts, and prominent businesspeople.

Key Programs and Organizations

The Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year awards inspire and set a positive example for everyone engaged in small business activities. This competition highlights the achievements of outstanding entrepreneurs, with criteria including quantitative factors like the growth rate of a company’s turnover, profit, and the number of jobs created, and qualitative aspects like the degree of innovation, the development of original products, creative marketing and sales solutions, and the scale of national and international presence. Entrepreneurs' Organization is another significant player in the entrepreneurial ecosystem, providing a global network of business owners who support each other through various stages of business development. The Scaleup Club and Dynamic Entrepreneurship Classroom programs help individuals grow their existing businesses and develop new skills. These initiatives contribute significantly to the overall climate of entrepreneurship by offering educational resources, funding opportunities, and a supportive community. The fusion of practical training, financial support, and mentorship through these programs ensures that aspiring entrepreneurs have all the tools they need to succeed.
page_cooked.page_title: Developing Entrepreneurs and Business Satisfaction
page_cooked.page_description: An insightful discussion on the development of entrepreneurial skills and the satisfaction of small business owners, highlighting key programs and competitions for aspiring entrepreneurs.
page_cooked.page_keywords: entrepreneurship, business development, small business, entrepreneurial education, Gallup-Healthways survey, startup funding

content_item.parsed_text: Subscribe to receive announcements about upcoming events in your city to receive our e-Bulletin (3 times a year) Last Name First Name Company Title E-mail Telephone City Industry - Agriculture Construction and Real Estate Consulting Food Industry Investor Legal Media NGO Production Other Russian Government Services Technology Transport/Logistics U.S. Government University Education Role Manager Entrepreneur Top Manager Instructor Government Employee Expert Student Other Submit Русский Join us on Facebook Twitter Subscribe For announcements of upcoming events and/or our e-Bulletin About Programs for Entrepreneurs Youth Entrepreneurship Initiatives Alliance for Entrepreneurship Development Matching Funding Resource Center Entrepreneurship Insights e-Bulletin Videos Press For Donors Partners Contacts ﻿ Promoting the Development of Entrepreneurship in Russia Маya Berdnikova, Vedomosti Business Newspaper Nizhny Novgorod The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship has celebrated the fifth anniversary of its operation in Moscow. This organization was created in 2002 by the U.S. Russia Investment Fund. The Center’s founder is Patricia Cloherty, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Delta Private Equity Partners. On March 17, 2008, President of the Russian Federation Vladimir Putin signed a decree awarding the Order of Friendship to Patricia M. Cloherty for her major contribution to the development of Russian business and for strengthening friendship and cooperation between the Russian Federation and the United States of America. The Center for Entrepreneurship has offices in Moscow, Nizhny Novgorod, and St. Petersburg. It serves as a model for setting up entrepreneurship centers in the countries of Eastern Europe, Central Asia, and the Middle East. In its short history, the Center already has succeeded in achieving splendid results, becoming a leader in its field, and putting into practice a highly effective means of support for entrepreneurs, one that serves as a powerful catalyst for the advancement of Russia’s entrepreneurial culture and the development of Russian business. On the occasion of its anniversary, the Center received congratulations from its partners and guests, including leading Russian businessmen, representatives of the business community and public organizations, academic institutions, and the media. Andrey Korkunov, vice president of the all-Russian organization of small and medium-sized businesses OPORA Rossii, offered words of gratitude on the organization’s behalf: “In the period of its existence, the Center has had a substantial influence on the course of political and economic development in Russia. Today, it is completely evident that when it comes to creating a favorable business climate and developing international relationships that can increase the attractiveness of the Russian economy to investors, the Center for Entrepreneurship is one of the most influential players. My words are confirmed by the indisputable reputation of the Center in the business community. For this, enormous credit is due to Victor Sedov, the Center’s Executive Director. It was he who succeeded in developing effective work on spreading ideas of entrepreneurship and on supporting programs and projects for the development of small and medium-sized businesses in Russia. There is no doubt that this course is the right one. With particular satisfaction, I note the high level of partner relations between the Center for Entrepreneurship and OPORA Rossii, which are based on trust. We act jointly in a number of areas that are of the utmost importance for the Russian economy, the chief of which is widespread efforts to get our fellow citizens involved in entrepreneurial activity and to teach them to create and develop businesses of their own.” Since the time of its creation, the Center has sought to develop an environment for networking and obtaining specialized knowledge that Russian entrepreneurs lack. Therefore, any educational program offered by the Center implies, above all, encounters of entrepreneurs with others of their kind. Anyone who wishes can attend the meetings of the Moscow, St. Petersburg, and Nizhny Novgorod Entrepreneur Groups, which the Center holds once each quarter. Opportunities for learning are provided in the form of a business breakfast, which generally packs the entire hall. The participants are attracted by the relevance of the topics and the chance to discuss them with major players in the Russian business community. Of course, not all entrepreneurs are prepared for open communication. Each one determines individually the degree of openness that is permissible for him/herself. For entrepreneurs who would like to systematize the knowledge they amass in one area or another, the Center offers educational programs based on the best international methods, presented by experts from leading American universities. Throughout America, tens of thousands of entrepreneurs have learned about business through the FastTrac™ program. This is a kind of mini-MBA course that enables students in a fairly short time to hone the skills needed to plan a business. The Center, together with Intel, launched FastTrac in Russia. All the instructors in this program have practical experience as businessmen and have been through a five-day training course given by American professionals. For three years now, the Center has sent, through its partners, professors from leading Russian universities to Harvard Business School. These participants all are interested in teaching entrepreneurship as an academic subject. Twice the Center has provided such instruction in Russia. According to evaluations by the Center for Entrepreneurship, the number of teachers who teach entrepreneurship courses for students and practicing businessmen in our country has reached a critical mass that makes it necessary to create a networking environment for these professionals as well. The Center initiated the creation of a Russian Association of Entrepreneurship Education. This association will be located at the Higher School of Management at St. Petersburg State University. Its purpose is to ensure all university and college teachers access to advanced knowledge about entrepreneurship and to give them an opportunity to network with colleagues from analogous associations in the United States and Europe. The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship has become one of the leading entities that advance the development of entrepreneurship in Russia. Every day more and more entrepreneurs begin to understand the value of networking with colleagues and learning from their experience. In the past four years, more than 11,000 entrepreneurs, politicians, and other professionals connected in one way or another to private business have taken part in the events organized and supported by the Center. The Center has helped Russian entrepreneurs establish ties with colleagues from other countries. Much still remains to be done to create conditions that would enable all Russian citizens to take advantage of economic opportunities. Nonetheless, the successful work of the Center over the course of the past five years instills confidence that entrepreneurship in Russia will flourish as before. April 28, 2008 ← Return to List of Articles Printable version © The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 2010 Site Map Development — Webmaster.SPb

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
The Center for Entrepreneurship Celebrates its Fifth Anniversary

April 28, 2008

Celebrating Milestones and Fostering Entrepreneurial Success

The Center for Entrepreneurship has marked its fifth anniversary, demonstrating its success in fostering a robust entrepreneurial culture. This organization, established in 2002 by the U.S. Russia Investment Fund, has made significant strides in supporting entrepreneurs through various initiatives. Patricia M. Cloherty, the founder, was honored with the Order of Friendship for her contributions to business development and international cooperation. The Center runs successful programs like Fasttrac, a mini-MBA course developed with Intel, to help entrepreneurs plan and grow their businesses. Additionally, the Center collaborates with universities to enhance entrepreneurship education and has sent professors to the Harvard Business School for specialized training.

Key Collaborations and Acknowledged Achievements

The Center for Entrepreneurship has established strong partnerships with key organizations worldwide. The Fasttrac program, developed in collaboration with Intel, offers a comprehensive business planning curriculum. This program connects participants to experienced business professionals and international experts. Furthermore, the Center initiated the creation of the Russian Association of Entrepreneurship Education, which works to enrich entrepreneurship teaching standards in academia. These efforts have facilitated an environment where entrepreneurs can network, exchange ideas, and gain valuable insights. The Center remains committed to nurturing growth in the entrepreneurial ecosystem, ensuring more individuals can leverage economic opportunities.

page_cooked.page_description: The Center for Entrepreneurship marked its fifth anniversary by celebrating its remarkable achievements and reinforced its role as a leading entity in promoting entrepreneurship.
page_cooked.page_keywords: Entrepreneurship, Center for Entrepreneurship, Business Development, Networking, Educational Programs, Patricia M. Cloherty, Delta Private Equity Partners, Order of Friendship, Business Community, Harvard Business School

The Center for Entrepreneurship Joins Canada in G20 Young Entrepreneur Summit

October 28, 2010

The Center for Entrepreneurship Joins Forces with G20 Nations

Next week, The Center for Entrepreneurship will join forces with other representatives of the G20 nations at the G20 Young Entrepreneur Summit hosted by the Canadian Youth Business Foundation to address the role of youth entrepreneurship as the world moves into the post-recovery phase. The summit aims to promote entrepreneurial initiatives and collaboration among young entrepreneurs across different nations.

Key Organizations Involved

Canadian Youth Business Foundation (CYBF) is one of Canada’s leading organizations dedicated to fostering young entrepreneurial talent. They provide mentorship, learning resources, and financial support to aspiring entrepreneurs. CYBF has played a crucial role in helping young Canadians start and grow successful businesses, contributing significantly to the nation's economic development. The organization is known for its initiatives such as the annual G20 YES, which encourages international collaboration and knowledge exchange among young business leaders. For more information, visit their website or check their various programs related to youth entrepreneurship excellence.

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
How Do You Learn Entrepreneurship?

May 1, 2008

Practical Tips on Learning Entrepreneurship

Executive Director of the Entrepreneurs Organization suggests picking up the necessary knowledge from people with practical experience who have taken the hands-on route to building their own companies. This hands-on approach helps budding entrepreneurs to understand real-world challenges and opportunities in the business world. The Scaleup Acceleration Program encourages this method by connecting new entrepreneurs with experienced mentors through various workshops and events.

Key Organizations Supporting Entrepreneurship

The U.S. Russia Investment Fund has been pivotal in promoting entrepreneurship. Founded by Patricia M. Cloherty, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Delta Private Equity Partners, the fund works tirelessly to foster a strong entrepreneurial ecosystem. On March 17, 2008, President of the Federation signed a decree awarding the Order of Friendship to Patricia M. Cloherty for her major contribution to the development of business and for strengthening cooperation between nations. Another key player is the Entrepreneurs Organization, which offers a variety of programs and initiatives to help aspiring entrepreneurs launch, grow, and scale their businesses.

page_cooked.page_description: Learn practical tips on acquiring entrepreneurship knowledge through hands-on experience and from experienced entrepreneurs.

On March 17, 2008, President of the Federation signed a decree awarding the Order of Friendship to Patricia M. Cloherty for her major contribution to the development of business and for strengthening cooperation between nations. Another key player is the Entrepreneurs Organization, which offers a variety of programs and initiatives to help aspiring entrepreneurs launch, grow, and scale their businesses.

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
The Center for Entrepreneurship Partners with My Business Magazine

April 15, 2003

Exciting New Partnerships and Initiatives for The Center for Entrepreneurship

The Center for Entrepreneurship has entered into several exciting partnerships and initiatives aimed at fostering entrepreneurial growth and providing valuable resources to young business owners. On April 10, 2003, My Business Magazine signed a partnership and cooperation agreement to become the general media partner, ensuring comprehensive informational support for the Center's educational and networking initiatives. In addition, an agreement was signed with OPORA, a non-governmental organization supporting small and medium businesses, to further enhance entrepreneurial opportunities. Moreover, the Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) opened its first chapter thanks to this collaboration. This chapter offers peer-to-peer advice, business information services, and global connections to select entrepreneurs under 40.

Key Organizations Driving Entrepreneurship

My Business Magazine is a widely recognized publication dedicated to helping entrepreneurs and business owners succeed. By becoming the general media partner for The Center for Entrepreneurship, the magazine will provide extensive coverage and support for various educational and networking programs. The OPORA organization plays a significant role in advocating for small and medium-sized enterprises, ensuring that these businesses have access to the necessary resources and support to thrive. The cooperation with The Center for Entrepreneurship will enable both entities to pool expertise and offer improved services to local entrepreneurs. The Young Entrepreneurs' Organization (YEO) is a global network that aids young entrepreneurs in building connections and accessing valuable business insights. The establishment of its first chapter through this collaboration will provide immense support to emerging business leaders.
page_cooked.page_title: The Center for Entrepreneurship Partners with My Business Magazine
page_cooked.page_description: The Center for Entrepreneurship signed a partnership agreement with My Business Magazine in April 2003 to provide informational support for various initiatives. Also notable is the cooperation agreement with OPORA and the establishment of the first Young Entrepreneurs' Chapter.

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
Learn about CFE's mission to promote entrepreneurship, our managing organizations, management, staff and contact information

January 23, 2004

Explore the Initiatives of the Center for Entrepreneurship

Welcome to the Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE). Learn about CFE's mission to promote entrepreneurship, its managing organizations, management, staff and contact information. The Center offers various learning and networking programs such as the Startup Huddle and the Young Entrepreneurs Alliance, which help entrepreneurs improve their business skills and overcome environmental challenges. Additionally, you can engage with the Dynamic Entrepreneurship Classroom to enhance your knowledge base. Our partnerships with organizations, including the Entrepreneurs' Organization, ensure a wide range of assistance is available to entrepreneurs. Find information about CFE in the media and explore a unique database that helps develop entrepreneurs and measures the vital signs of the emerging entrepreneurial economy. Our guide is easy to use for finding your way around our website.

Information about Key Organizations and Programs

Entrepreneurs' Organization: A global network of entrepreneurs that offers peer-to-peer learning, networking, and continuous personal growth opportunities. The organization focuses on driving business growth, engaging in community impact initiatives, and representing the voice of entrepreneurs on the global stage. The various learning and motivational programs by the organization include workshops, seminars, and online resources designed to help entrepreneurs at any stage of their business journey. Their emphasis on mentorship and real-world experiences ensures that members receive valuable insights and actionable advice that can be implemented in their businesses. Furthermore, the organization collaborates with numerous partners to foster an ecosystem supportive of entrepreneurial growth.

Welcome to CFE

January 29, 2004

Learn About CFE's Mission and Programs

Welcome to the Center for Entrepreneurship! Learn about CFE's mission to promote entrepreneurship, our managing organizations, management, staff, and contact information. We offer a variety of learning and networking programs to help entrepreneurs improve their business skills and overcome environmental challenges. Discover our partnerships with organizations that enable us to provide an extensive range of assistance. We have compiled a unique database of information that helps develop entrepreneurs and measure the vital signs of the emerging entrepreneurial economy. Additionally, we provide media information and an easy-to-use guide to navigate our website.

Key Organizations and Their Contributions

Entrepreneurs' Organization - This organization provides extensive support through programs such as Global Entrepreneurship Week and Scaleup Acceleration Program. These initiatives help foster the development of new businesses and support established entrepreneurs in scaling their operations. Another significant partner is the Kauffman Foundation, known for their Fasttrac program, which offers comprehensive training courses for aspiring entrepreneurs. Additionally, SCORE provides mentoring and guidance to help new businesses flourish, contributing significantly to the entrepreneurial ecosystem.

- News russian version News Winner Announced in the 2004 Russian Entrepreneur Of The Year Contest November 26, 2004 - Rouben Vardanyan, President of Troika Dialog Group, Wins the National Entrepreneur Of The Year Contest in Russia The EOY annual contest is being held by Ernst & Young in Russia for the second time in 2004. This national contest is part of Ernst & Young's international Entrepreneur Of The Year© Award program, launched 18 years ago (1986) and established to recognize and honor outstanding entrepreneurial achievements in developing the global and national economies. details... Young CEOs hold summit in Moscow November 2003 - Young CEOs from all over the globe gathered in Moscow to share their experiences on private entrepreneurship and map out strategies for the future Moscow temporarily became the center for young business owners and/or CEOs from all over the world at the annual Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) and the World Entrepreneurs Organization (WEO) European Conference. details... MEDIA RELEASE:  Russian Entrepreneurs Rate Their Business Training Needs Aptil 20, 2004 - Entrepreneurs of Mid-Sized Companies in Moscow Participate in a Survey to Rate Their Business Skills and Personal Development Needs Moscow, Russia - Russian entrepreneurs of mid-sized companies rated Strategic Planning the most in-demand business training program, with one-day, peer-to-peer learning the most preferred learning format, according to results of a survey commissioned by the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE).... details... Kalashnikovs Well-Aimed Shot March 2004 - Andrey Kalashnikov, a young businessman from Penza, is the winner of the Business Breakthrough competition, a joint project of My Business magazine and the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship. In less than four years, starting from scratch, he built a manufacturing company with a turnover of US $1.2 million. details... TOP FIVE - Judges of the Business Breakthrough Competition Have Come up with the Top Five Finalists. January 2004 - Judges of the Business Breakthrough competition have come up with the top five finalists. The winner is to be determined by the results of the second round in February.  The Business Breakthrough competition, a joint project of My Business magazine and the US-Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, aims at highlighting the experiences of young and fast-growing Russian companies... details... USP Compulink and Delta Capital Management / The US Russia Investment Fund Announce a Major Investment November 5, 2003 - Delta Capital Management, manager of The US Russia Investment Fund, announced today that it is making a significant investment in USP Compulink. This investment will allow USP Compulink to expand its business to meet the rapidly growing needs of the Russian IT market. The Fund is the founder of The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship. details... It Takes an Entrepreneur to Teach an Entrepreneur October 2003 - The European conference of the Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) will be held in Moscow on October 10  11, 2003.  This became possible thanks to the assistance of the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship.  The president of the organizations Moscow chapter, Mikhail Kupriyanov, discusses the unique opportunities YEO provides its members. details... Young Entrepreneurs Visit Moscow - Global Business Leaders Attend European Regional Conference October 2003 - Nearly 100 members and guests of the Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO), the premier, peer-to-peer global community, network and resource for entrepreneurs, will be gathering for a European Regional Conference at the Moscow Marriott Aurora Hotel in Moscow, Russia, from 9-12 October, 2003 to attend an international four-day conference.  This exclusive event, an annual regional conference for YEO, in partnership with the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship .... details... The Cream of the Crop in Business - Ernst & Young Begins Entrepreneur of the Year award in Russia July 28, 2003 - The publishing house Kommersant has become a media sponsor of the Entrepreneur of the Year award program, which Ernst & Young, the worlds largest auditing and consulting firm, has conducted annually for 17 years. Now Russian entrepreneurs as well have gained an opportunity to participate in this competition, and this step indicates that business in this country has acquired a deserving reputation in the international arena.  Among the sponsors of the award program are the management company Yevrazkholding, Renessans Kapital, the agency Mikhaylov and Partners, and the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship . details... My Business Magazine Announces a new Contest for Entrepreneurs: Business Breakthrough" Business Breakthrough, a contest sponsored by My Business magazine and The U.S.-Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, is open to owners of small and medium-sized Russian companies that have achieved high rates of growth.  The winner of the competition will be awarded a two-week internship in a U.S. company in his or her field. details... page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
Winner Announced in the 2004 Entrepreneur Of The Year Contest

November 26, 2004

Rouben Vardanyan Wins National Entrepreneur Of The Year Contest

Rouben Vardanyan, President of Troika Dialog Group, emerged as the winner of the national Entrepreneur Of The Year Contest, which was held for the second time by Ernst & Young in 2004. This esteemed contest is an integral component of Ernst & Young's international Entrepreneur Of The Year® Award program. Launched 18 years ago in 1986, the program aims to honor and recognize exceptional entrepreneurial achievements that contribute to the global and national economies.

Key Organizations Contributing to the Success of the Entrepreneur Of The Year Contest

Ernst & Young, a global leader in assurance, tax, transaction, and advisory services, conducts the Entrepreneur Of The Year® Award program annually. EY has been instrumental in supporting and recognizing entrepreneurs who have made significant impacts on the business landscape. Another notable organization involved is Troika Dialog Group, whose President, Rouben Vardanyan, was honored this year. The contest also sees participation from companies like Yevrazkholding, Renessans Kapital, and the agency Mikhaylov and Partners, who support the event through sponsorship and media partnerships. The Center for Entrepreneurship played a pivotal role in organizing and promoting the contest, ensuring it reached a wide array of entrepreneurs and business leaders.

page_cooked.page_keywords: Entrepreneur of the Year, 2004 Entrepreneur Contest, business awards, entrepreneurial achievements, Center for Entrepreneurship

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
Winner Announced in the 2004 Entrepreneur Of The Year Contest

November 26, 2004

Rouben Vardanyan Wins Entrepreneur Of The Year 2004 in National Contest

Rouben Vardanyan, President of Troika Dialog Group, has won the national Entrepreneur Of The Year Contest in 2004. This annual contest is part of Ernst & Young's international Entrepreneur Of The Year Award program. Established 18 years ago, the program aims to recognize and honor outstanding entrepreneurial achievements in developing the global and national economies.

About Ernst & Young and Troika Dialog Group

Ernst & Young is one of the largest professional services networks in the world, offering audit, tax, consulting, and advisory services to companies across multiple industries. The organization is renowned for its commitment to building a better working world by providing insights and quality services that foster trust and confidence in capital markets and economies globally.

Troika Dialog Group, led by President Rouben Vardanyan, is a leading private investment house. Under Vardanyan's leadership, the group has grown significantly, helping to shape the investment landscape by providing financial advisory, asset management, and brokerage services. Troika Dialog is known for its innovative solutions and strategic partnerships, playing a crucial role in the financial sector.

- News russian version News Andrey Martirosov was awarded Entrepreneur of the Year in Russia. The General Director of airline UTair has been named the national winner of the international competition Entrepreneur of Year, 2005 organized by Ernst and Young. Andrey Martirosov, having headed airline UTair since 1999, has brought back the enterprise from bankruptcy and has transformed it into an industry leader.  In 2006, the company plans to earn 400 million rubles net profit, four times more than the 2005 figure. In June 2006, Mr. Martikrosov will represent at the international Entrepreneur of the Year competition in Monte-Carlo. Other winners of the Entrepreneur of the Year competition in Russia  were the General Director, Sibirsky Bereg, Alexander Ladan; Chairman of Board of Directors, Euroset, Evgeny Chichvarkin; General Director, Continent Express, Stanislav Kostiashkin; General Director, MAGRAM Market Research, Marina Malyhina; General Director, Digital Design, Andrey Fedorov; Chairman of Board, NBD-BANK, Alexander Sharonov;  President, Global Age, Michael Lifshits; President, The Microfinance Center, Paul Sigal; and the Rector of the St.-Petersburg International Institute of Management, Sergey Mordovin. details... Russias Business Leaders of Tomorrow Between 17 and 25 September 2005 sixteen participants of Russias Business Leaders of Tomorrow, Our Talents Foundation program for MBA students of Moscows leading business schools, had a tremendous opportunity to take part in a series of meetings in the UK. The meetings were held with some of the UKs leading institutions and figures in politics, business, public administration, mass media, NGOs and education. details... page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
Entrepreneur Of The Year Contest Winner Announced

September 26, 2006

Andrey Martirosov Named Entrepreneur Of The Year 2005 By Ernst & Young

Andrey Martirosov, the General Director of airline UTair, has been recognized as the national winner of the esteemed Entrepreneur of the Year, 2005 competition organized by Ernst & Young. Under his leadership since 1999, UTair emerged from bankruptcy and transformed into a leading industry player. The company forecasted a 400 million rubles net profit in 2006, quadrupling its 2005 performance. Mr. Martirosov will represent at the international Entrepreneur of the Year competition in Monte-Carlo this June. Other winners include leaders from various industries, setting a high standard of excellence and innovation across the business landscape.

Prominent Business Recognition and Development Programs

The Center for Entrepreneurship consistently supports and propels entrepreneurial talent through various programs. The Acceleration Programs help businesses scale up and achieve sustainable growth. Another notable initiative is the Entrepreneurs' Organization, which provides a platform for young CEOs to share experiences and formulate strategies for future growth. Additionally, the Center emphasizes the importance of peer-to-peer learning through brief but impactful training formats, reflecting the high demand for strategic planning skills among mid-sized company entrepreneurs. With this focus on development, the organization fosters an environment where entrepreneurial spirit and innovation can thrive.

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
Franchising – Business Perspectives in Nizhny Novgorod

March 15, 2006

Conference-Exhibition on Franchising in Nizhny Novgorod

On March 15, 2006, the Nizhny Novgorod Regional Ministry for Small Business Support and Development, the Nizhny Novgorod Retailers' Association, and the Center for Entrepreneurship co-hosted a franchising fair/conference. Supported by the Russian Franchising Association and Consulting group Store for Prepared Businesses, the event showcased the potential of franchising as a robust business model.

Key Organizations Supporting the Event

The Russian Franchising Association aims to foster the development of franchising systems and enhance the business environment for franchise enterprises. It is pivotal in uniting franchisors and franchisees, promoting a cooperative network to ensure business success. Consulting group Store for Prepared Businesses specializes in offering franchising opportunities, helping entrepreneurs find and acquire franchises. It assists in the preparation and development of franchise documents, market analysis, and connecting investors with viable business models. These organizations play a crucial role in shaping the future of franchising in the region, providing essential support and guidance to new and existing franchise businesses.

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
Iron Entrepreneur Competition

March 18, 2006

Iron Entrepreneur Competition Showcases Student Talent

On March 18, 2006, the NN Branch of Higher School of Economics and The Center for Entrepreneurship conducted a students competition, Iron Entrepreneur. This event was designed to provide a platform for young entrepreneurs to showcase their innovative business ideas and entrepreneurial skills. The competition saw enthusiastic participation from students eager to make their mark in the world of business.

Key Organizations and Their Roles

Ernst & Young, now officially known as EY, is a multinational professional services firm headquartered in London, England. EY is one of the largest professional services networks in the world. It primarily provides assurance (including financial audit), tax, consulting, and advisory services to companies. In addition to its role in the Iron Entrepreneur Competition, EY is also known for recognizing and honoring entrepreneurial achievements through its international Entrepreneur of the Year program. This program celebrates the accomplishments of entrepreneurs who have made significant contributions to their industries and communities.
page_cooked.page_title: Iron Entrepreneur Competition
page_cooked.page_description: The Center for Entrepreneurship recently held the Iron Entrepreneur Competition alongside the Higher School of Economics, providing a platform for students to showcase their entrepreneurial skills.

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
Andrey Martirosov was awarded Entrepreneur of the Year

September 26, 2006

Andrey Martirosov, General Director of UTair, Recognized for Leadership and Achievements

Andrey Martirosov, the General Director of airline UTair, has been honored as the national winner of the international competition Entrepreneur of the Year 2005, organized by Ernst & Young. Under his leadership since 1999, UTair has recovered from bankruptcy and evolved into an industry leader. In 2006, the company aims to achieve a net profit of 400 million rubles, quadrupling its 2005 performance. Mr. Martirosov will represent at the international Entrepreneur of the Year competition in Monte-Carlo. The event also celebrated other notable leaders in business, including Alexander Ladan, Evgeny Chichvarkin, Stanislav Kostiashkin, Marina Malyhina, Andrey Fedorov, Alexander Sharonov, Michael Lifshits, Paul Sigal, and Sergey Mordovin.

Key Organizations in Entrepreneurial Development

Ernst & Young hosts the Entrepreneur of the Year competition to recognize and honor outstanding entrepreneurial achievements worldwide. Established 18 years ago, the program supports and encourages business leaders who contribute significantly to global and national economic development. The Center for Entrepreneurship is dedicated to fostering entrepreneurial spirit and growth through various initiatives, including the Global Entrepreneurship Week and the Dynamic Entrepreneurship Classroom. These programs offer valuable resources and opportunities for startups and established businesses looking to scale. The organization collaborates with industry leaders to provide insights and best practices, ensuring the continued success and competitiveness of enterprises.

Winner Announced in the 2004 Entrepreneur Of The Year Contest

November 26, 2004

National Entrepreneur Of The Year Contest Winners

Rouben Vardanyan, President of Troika Dialog Group, emerged as the winner of the 2004 Entrepreneur Of The Year Contest, organized by Ernst & Young. The award aims to recognize and honor outstanding entrepreneurial achievements in fostering global and national economies. Some notable winners included Alexander Ladan, Stanislav Kostiashkin, Marina Malyhina, Andrey Fedorov, Alexander Sharonov, Michael Lifshits, Paul Sigal, and Sergey Mordovin.

Key Organizations Recognized for Their Contributions

The Ernst & Young Entrepreneur Of The Year program has been recognizing outstanding entrepreneurs since its inception in 1986. It provides a platform for inspiring business leaders who have significantly contributed to the growth of their enterprises. Troika Dialog Group, under the leadership of Rouben Vardanyan, has consistently played a key role in the investment banking sector. Since 1991, Troika Dialog has been at the forefront of developing financial markets and investment opportunities. The Economist has often featured their strategic business moves and influential market presence. Marina Malyhina of MAGRAM Market Research additionally signifies the role of market research in guiding companies towards data-driven decision-making, showcasing the valuable synergy between research and business strategy.

Entrepreneurship Group: Delegating Duties to Sustain Growth

June 7, 2006

Strategies for Effective Growth Management

The Center for Entrepreneurship and My Business Magazine hosted an event on June 7, 2006, focusing on how entrepreneurs and hired managers can sustain fast growth through effective duty delegation. Notable speakers included entrepreneur Dmitry Agarunov, owner of (game)land; service sector expert Ekaterina Ryazantseva, managing partner of Anderson Partners; and hired general manager Valery Lukovnikov, general manager of New Idea Investment Group.

Key Organizations and Their Roles

My Business Magazine is renowned for publishing insightful content for entrepreneurs, including the famous My Business magazine, which caters to a wide readership of business owners and managers. Anderson Partners is a significant consultancy firm providing various services to enhance business efficiency, while New Idea Investment Group is prominent in funding innovative business ideas across multiple sectors. Together, these organizations contribute to fostering an environment where entrepreneurship can thrive and develop sustainably.

content_item.parsed_text:
The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- News russian version News Monday, January 27, 2003, 12:49 pm  Young Entrepreneurs Organization and The US Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Announce New Partnership Establish First-Ever YEO Chapter in Russia Washington, DC/Moscow - Working to broaden its global network of young entrepreneurs in every corner of the globe, the Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO), the leading entrepreneurial organization for young business-owners under the age of 40, has formed a unique partnership with The US Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE), a catalyst organization advancing the role and scope of entrepreneurship in Russia through a combination of education and networking activities targeted to entrepreneurs of growing companies. YEO and CFE are working together to further entrepreneurship in Russia by introducing Russian entrepreneurs to the extensive networking and knowledge resources of YEO. To introduce Russian entrepreneurs to the powerful benefits of YEO, CFE recruited four Russian entrepreneurs to be local YEO charter members and accompanied them to YEOs European Conference in Paris, France in November 2002. These charter members are now working with CFE to bring in new members and to establish the first-ever YEO Moscow Chapter, which officially launches on February 6, 2003, with a special ceremony. Plans are also underway to form a St. Petersburg Chapter, and to hold YEOs European Conference in Moscow in September 2003. I believe this new strategic partnership with The US Russia Center for Entrepreneurship will prove valuable as YEO grows and expands its global outreach into Eastern Europe, explains 2003 YEO President Sean Magennis, an entrepreneur from Dallas, Texas. It also provides a place for Russian entrepreneurs to find the peer-to-peer advice and support they seek not only locally, but also worldwide with YEOs nearly 5,000 members. Under this partnership, CFE has pledged sponsorship, administrative, recruiting and logistical assistance to YEO and its Russian chapters to ensure YEOs success in Russia . . By helping YEO expand into Russia, CFE is fulfilling its mission to accelerate entrepreneurship in Russia by providing unique educational, networking and exchange opportunities targeted specifically to Russian entrepreneurs leading growth companies. CFE is enthusiastic about our new partnership with YEO, states Victor Sedov, Director of The US Russia Center for Entrepreneurship. By giving Russian entrepreneurs access to YEOs network of successful entrepreneurs, we are exposing them to worldwide best business practices, introducing them to potential international partners, and in turn, helping to raise the prominence of entrepreneurship in Russia as a force for economic development, wealth creation and job generation. The Young Entrepreneurs Organization is the premier, peer-to-peer, global community, network and resource for entrepreneurs. Since 1987, this international nonprofit educational organization has helped its members build upon their successes through an array of learning and networking opportunities. With members in more than 142 cities, spanning 35 countries, YEOs rapidly expanding membership includes entrepreneurs from every size and type of business. YEO membership has increased by some 20 percent last year, and now is nearly 5,000 members strong. Membership in YEO is by invitation only, and is subject to approval by both YEO International and the sponsoring local chapter. Prospective YEO members must be under 40 years of age and be a founder, co-founder, owner or controlling shareholder of a business with gross annual revenues exceeding (US) $1 million. Members graduate from YEO in the year they turn 40, and are encouraged to then join World Entrepreneurs Organization. www.yeo.org The US Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE) is the leading provider of education and network learning activities targeting the needs of growth entrepreneurs in Russia. CFE serves Russian entrepreneurs to assist them in developing their companies, while facilitating the entrepreneurial process in Russia. CFE promotes entrepreneurship as a positive force for economic vitality and social advancement by bringing together entrepreneurs with policymakers and investors in a learning environment that supports and advances the role and scope of entrepreneurship in Russia. CFE is an initiative of The U.S. Russia Investment Fund, a leading private equity fund in Russia, and managed in cooperation with the Foundation for Enterprise Development, a foremost educational organization dedicated to building high performing entrepreneurial organizations. www.cfe.ru Contact: Karen Seidman, YEO, VP, Communications & Marketing, kseidman@yeo.org , (703) 519-6700 x129 Matt Mladenka, YEO Strategic Alliance/Press Manager, mmladenka@yeo.org , (972) 650-4115 Eric Hansen, CFE, Program Manager, ehansen@cfe.ru , 7 (095) 252-7927 Melinda Maas-Gaffney, Beyster Institute, PR Manager, maasgaffneym@beysterinstitute.org , (858) 826-1690 back My Business Magazine Media Partner OPORA Russia Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

Young Entrepreneurs Organization and The Center for Entrepreneurship Announce New Partnership

January 27, 2003

Young Entrepreneurs Organization Expands Global Reach with New Partnership

Working to broaden its global network of young entrepreneurs, the Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO), the leading entrepreneurial organization for young business-owners under the age of 40, has formed a unique partnership with The Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE). YEO and CFE are working together to further entrepreneurship by introducing entrepreneurs to the extensive networking and knowledge resources of YEO. To introduce these benefits, CFE recruited four entrepreneurs to be local YEO charter members and accompanied them to YEO's European Conference in Paris, France in November 2002. These charter members are now working with CFE to bring in new members and to establish the first-ever YEO Chapter, which officially launches on February 6, 2003, with a special ceremony. Plans are also underway to hold YEO's European Conference in September 2003.

About the Young Entrepreneurs Organization and Center for Entrepreneurship

The Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) is the premier, peer-to-peer, global community, network, and resource for entrepreneurs. Since 1987, this international nonprofit educational organization has helped its members build upon their successes through an array of learning and networking opportunities. With members in more than 142 cities spanning 35 countries, YEO's rapidly expanding membership includes entrepreneurs from every size and type of business. Membership in YEO is by invitation only and is subject to approval by both YEO International and the sponsoring local chapter. Prospective YEO members must be under 40 years of age and be a founder, co-founder, owner, or controlling shareholder of a business with gross annual revenues exceeding $1 million. Members graduate from YEO in the year they turn 40 and are encouraged to then join World Entrepreneurs Organization (WEO).

content_item.parsed_text:
The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- News russian version News Saturday, February 15, 2003, 2:43 pm  YEO and The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship open first Russian YEO Chapter Moscow, February 6. /PRIME-TASS/. The Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) at the initiative of The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship opened its first Russian chapter in Moscow, Sean Magennis, President of YEO announced during a briefing today. He stated that YEO and The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship have combined their efforts to support entrepreneurship in Russia by giving Russian entrepreneurs access to YEOs networks and information resources.  Within the framework of this partnership The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship plans to render financial, administrative, staff and organizational assistance to YEO and its Russian chapters. There are currently 5,000 YEO members.  The average age of the entrepreneurs is 35. The average revenue of each members company is $9 million a year.  The organization has 120 chapters in 34 countries.  An entrepreneur up to 40 years of age, who owns, founded or is a partner in a company with minimum revenues of $1 million a year can become a member of the organization. According to The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurships managing director Victor Sedov, the Moscow Chapter will have more than one thousand young entrepreneurs in several years.  YEO Moscow chapter president, entrepreneur Mikhail Kupriyanov, believes that by the end of 2003, 25-30 people will become members of the chapter.  Mr. Sedov says that already several entrepreneurs from the largest Russian enterprises working in the food, computer and technology, PR, and other industries have already become members of the Moscow chapter.  Mr. Sedov didnt name the companies. According to him, YEO branch offices are financed through annual fees.  To become a member of YEO, entrepreneurs have to pay $790 in annual fees.  Fees can also be paid within each chapter; the amount determined separately by each chapter. According to Mr. Magennis, a YEO branch office is going to be opened in Saint-Petersburg in 2003. The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship is one of the leading organizations in Russia working to satisfying the needs of entrepreneurs of fast growing companies by providing education and networking opportunities.  The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship was created by the initiative of The U.S. Russia Investment Fund, a leader in private equity in Russia, and is managed by the Foundation for Enterprise Development. February 6, 2003, 20:25:22 Author: PRIME-TASS back My Business Magazine Media Partner OPORA Russia Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
YEO and The Center for Entrepreneurship Open First YEO Chapter

February 15, 2003

YEO Partners with The Center for Entrepreneurship to Launch First Chapter

The Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) at the initiative of The Center for Entrepreneurship opened its first chapter. Sean Magennis, President of YEO, announced the launch during a briefing. YEO and The Center for Entrepreneurship have combined efforts to support entrepreneurship by giving entrepreneurs access to YEO's networks and resources. As part of this partnership, The Center for Entrepreneurship plans to provide financial, administrative, and organizational assistance to YEO and its chapters. YEO currently has 5,000 members, with an average age of 35 and average company revenue of $9 million per year. The organization has 120 chapters in 34 countries. Entrepreneurs under 40 who own, founded, or partner in a company with minimum revenues of $1 million per year can become members. The chapter expects over one thousand entrepreneurs in several years. The chapter president believes that by the end of 2003, 25-30 members will join. YEO branches are financed through annual fees, with membership costing $790 annually. There are also plans to open another branch office later in 2003. The Center for Entrepreneurship offers educational and networking opportunities to meet the needs of entrepreneurs of fast-growing companies.

Key Organizations Involved

The Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) is a global network of young business owners, providing peer-to-peer learning and connections to enhance business growth. Established in 1987, YEO unites entrepreneurs across various industries to foster innovation and support. Membership benefits include access to networking events, mentorship, and resources tailored to entrepreneurial needs. YEO's mission is to engage, educate, and empower entrepreneurs, helping them scale their businesses and achieve new heights of success. By partnering with The Center for Entrepreneurship, YEO aims to broaden its impact and provide an extensive support system for emerging business leaders. This collaboration exemplifies their commitment to nurturing entrepreneurial talent through strategic alliances and knowledge sharing.

content_item.parsed_text:
The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- News russian version News Friday, February 28, 2003, 5:18 pm  New opportunity opens for entrepreneurs under 40 The Young Entrepreneurs Organization has come to Moscow, offering peer-to-peer advice, business information services and links to fellow entrepreneurs worldwide.  But only a select few under-40s can apply to join. Young Russian businesspeople are set to receive worldwide support after the opening of an office in Moscow by the Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO). The YEO, which helps business owners under the age of 40 worldwide, will run its Moscow chapter through a partnership with the U.S.-Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE). The CFE was formed by the U.S.-Russia Investment Fund, a leading private equity fund in Russia, and is managed in cooperation with the Foundation for Enterprise Development, an educational organization dedicated to building high-performing entrepreneurial organizations. "I believe this new strategic partnership with the CFE will prove valuable as the YEO grows and expands its global outreach into the former East European bloc, beginning from Moscow, the YEOs first chapter in the region," said YEO President Sean Magennis. "Itll also provide a place for Russian entrepreneurs to find the peer-to-peer advice and support they seek  not only locally, but also worldwide among the YEOs 5,000 members in more than 142 cities spread over 35 countries." Member companies control more than $51 billion in combined revenues and employ nearly 500,000 people, he added. Magennis told The Russia Journal in an interview that the YEO has always been enthusiastic about coming to Russia, but that the communist system made it impossible for Western entrepreneurs to establish contact. And, after the break up of the U.S.S.R., time was needed to seek out appropriate partners. "It took us time to plan and search for the right people in the Moscow business community to open a chapter in Moscow. But now, that we are here, we plan to spend several hundreds of thousands dollars over the next five years to support our youngest chapter," he said. "In return, we expect to get new members, fresh business ideas and new market for YEO members and their products." However, membership in the YEO, which is only by invitation, is subject to approval by both the YEO International and the sponsoring local chapter, Magennis said. "To qualify, a prospective YEO member must be under 40 years of age and be a founder, co-founder, owner or controlling shareholder of a business with gross annual revenues exceeding $1 million," he added. Members graduate from the YEO in the year they turn 40 and are encouraged to then join the World Entrepreneurs Organization. Magennis said the YEOs members pay annual dues of $800, which gives them access to the organizations versatile business-information resources and other facilities to run their businesses more effectively. "Special programs, including those where experts are invited to address the audience, may attract extra fees, but these and other issues are exclusive prerogatives of local chapters," he added. The CFEs director, Viktor Sedov, was equally upbeat about the program. "We are enthusiastic about our new partnership with the YEO, because by giving Russian entrepreneurs access to the YEOs network of successful entrepreneurs, we are exposing them to worldwide best-business practices and potential international partners," he said. "And, this, in turn, will help to raise the prominence of entrepreneurship in Russia as a force for economic development, wealth creation and job generation," he said. Sedov also noted that plans were underway to form a St. Petersburg chapter and to hold YEOs European Conference in Moscow later in September. Sergei Vasilyev, chairman of the Federation Councils Committee for Finance and Budget Planning, said it was a great idea to open a YEO chapter in Moscow. "It will create a forum for an exchange of business ideas. And, specifically, it will allow the YEOs members worldwide to come and learn from Russian entrepreneurs unique secrets and experience of running businesses effectively in financial conditions similar to those in war-zone areas," he added. Daniel Wild, the president of the YEO in Germany, which was founded in 2000 with only 20 members, and the CEO of Getmobile in Munich, said he came to support the organizations new chapter in Moscow. "We are all here to support the Moscow chapter because Russia is a European country with a lot of opportunities, and networking among the YEOs members will allow us to develop a better business relationship with the country," he said. February 14-20, 2002.
