page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
New opportunity opens for entrepreneurs under 40

April 10, 2003

The Young Entrepreneurs' Organization launches new chapter

The Young Entrepreneurs Organization has come to unveil a chapter with the Center for Entrepreneurship, providing peer-to-peer advice, business information services, and links to fellow entrepreneurs worldwide. Only a select few under-40s can apply to join. The YEO helps business owners under the age of 40 worldwide and plans to spend several hundred thousand dollars over the next five years to support the youngest chapter. To qualify, a prospective YEO member must be under 40 years of age and be a founder, co-founder, owner, or controlling shareholder of a business with gross annual revenues exceeding $1 million. Membership in the YEO, which is invite-only, is subject to approval by both YEO International and the sponsoring local chapter. Members graduate from the YEO in the year they turn 40 and are then encouraged to join the World Entrepreneurs Organization. The Center for Entrepreneurship director, Patricia M. Cloherty, was equally upbeat about the program.

About the Young Entrepreneurs' Organization

The Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) is a dynamic global network of young businesspeople. Established to foster entrepreneurship by providing networking opportunities and business resources, YEO operates in over 142 cities and 35 countries, boasting a membership of over 5000 successful entrepreneurs. Participants gain access to peer-to-peer learning, educational events focused on driving their businesses forward, and valuable mentorship connections. Membership dues amount to $800 annually, facilitating access to a wealth of business information and resources, with special programs addressing key topics often subject to additional fees as decided by local chapters. The organization controls combined revenues of more than $51 billion and employs nearly 500,000 people globally.

content_item.parsed_text:
The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- News russian version News Wednesday, March 5, 2003, 12:45 pm  OPORA Russia and The US Russia Center For Entrepreneurship A cooperation agreement between the Russian non-governmental organization of small and medium businesses OPORA Russia and The US Russia Center for Entrepreneurship has been signed in Moscows President Hotel. Heads of each delegation, Victor Sedov, Executive Director of the Center for Entrepreneurship (US citizen) and Sergei Borisov, President of OPORA Russia, signed a document saying that the organizations are uniting their efforts to support entrepreneurship in the Russian Federation.  As was clear from their brief statements, they intend to encourage international cooperation with Russian entrepreneurs, in turn, raising Russias business and investment attractiveness in the international business community.  The partnership agreement outlines steps to achieve this goal through cooperative informational and consultancy services.  For instance, the parties intend to exchange information about the goods and services markets of each country.  OPORA Russia also will identify reputable entrepreneurs for exchange visits between the two countries, to be sponsored by The US Center for Entrepreneurship. Both organizations will hold joint seminars, conferences, presentations, round tables and exhibitions, and help each other in marketing each others programs.  Also, special training courses covering best business practices of each country will be organized to help learn about the market of both countries.  The US Russia Center for Entrepreneurship has offered to developed a curriculum for one-year entrepreneurial training in marketing, raising capital, corporate governance, personnel management, and financial transparency.  In its turn, OPORA Russia undertakes to provide assistance of its regional branches in holding The US-Russia Center for Entrepreneurships events at their sites. There are more substantial plans as well.  In an exclusive interview with Business for Everyone , Victor Sedov, Executive Director of The US Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, said that this agreement with OPORA compliments the Centers work to introduce the Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) into Russia.  YEO is headquartered in the USA with members in 142 cities around the world.  Their entry into Russia will facilitate a direct dialog between entrepreneurs from 35 countries.  YEO already has a positive vision of Russia.  And, they are going to hold their European Conference in Moscow in September 2003, with around 200 entrepreneurs expected to attend to start business relationships in Russia. This is not just formal signing of a friendly agreement, commented Sergei Borisov.  The Center has concrete plans to help promote progressive entrepreneurship and has a mission to assist in the development of growth enterprises.  The agreement proposes a joint study into violations and protection of entrepreneurs rights in Russia, resulting in a report to be submitted to the Russian Presidential Human Rights Commission.  It is noteworthy that the Center approached OPORA Russia with a proposal for cooperation.  The reason is that we represent an organization uniting real entrepreneurs.  We were approached because our organization is becoming prominent abroad, not only in Russia.  We have also been sought out by France, China, Slovakia, and Switzerland.  The international community is looking to us because OPORA Russia is a door opening, with hopes for effective business support on the other side.  Opening it, entrepreneurs find themselves not amongst bureaucrats, but with fellow entrepreneurs. page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
Entrepreneurs Join Their U.S. Counterparts in Peer-Learning Experience

June 23, 2003

U.S. and International Entrepreneurs Collaborate for Growth

Recognizing an opportunity for expanded international cooperation and the fact that entrepreneurs learn best from each other, the Foundation for Enterprise Development (FED) and the Center for Entrepreneurship, in partnership with the Young Entrepreneurs' Organization (YEO), are hosting the 'The U.S. Russia Entrepreneurs Exchange,' a peer-learning program that links American entrepreneurs from May 29 through June 6, 2003. The program aims to encourage international cooperation with entrepreneurs, raising business and investment attractiveness in the international business community. Steps outlined include exchanging information about goods and services markets and organizing conferences, presentations, and seminars. Special training covering best business practices will also be organized. The partnership focuses on marketing, raising capital, corporate governance, personnel management, and financial transparency. Plans are underway to introduce the Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) into new markets, facilitating a direct dialog between entrepreneurs from 35 countries. A European Conference in September 2003 will further business relationships globally.

Key Organizations and Their Initiatives

The Foundation for Enterprise Development (FED) plays a pivotal role in promoting peer learning among entrepreneurs. They aim to bridge gaps between small business communities globally through various initiatives. The Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) is a network dedicated to young business leaders, fostering connections and providing resources to help them succeed. This organization, which has members in multiple countries, offers significant opportunities for entrepreneurial growth through events, networking, and educational programs. Their efforts not only focus on local development but also emphasize forming international business relationships that can lead to broader market opportunities.

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
New Partnership Announced by The Center for Entrepreneurship and My Business Magazine

April 10, 2003

Partnership to Provide Entrepreneurs with Enhanced Educational and Networking Opportunities

The Center for Entrepreneurship and My Business Magazine have signed a partnership and cooperation agreement. Under this agreement, My Business Magazine will serve as the general media partner, offering informational support for the Center's educational initiatives and networking events. Additionally, My Business will publish interviews with Western consultants and entrepreneurs participating in the Center's programs. The Center for Entrepreneurship will help establish contacts with leading business management experts, broaden networking opportunities among entrepreneurs, and feature My Business’ logo on promotional materials. The collaboration also includes mutual marketing and PR support, with discussions underway for sponsorship and participation in the national Open Your Own Business! competition. The Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) is one of the Center's closest partners, and with assistance from the Center, the YEO European conference will take place in October 2003, marking a significant event for over 150 YEO members worldwide.

Key Organizations Involved in Expanded Entrepreneurial Support

The Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) has been pivotal in fostering a robust network of over 5,000 young business leaders from 35 countries. The organization's peer-learning model is designed to enhance the entrepreneurial experience by enabling members to share knowledge and strategies directly with one another. This model is now more accessible to entrepreneurs associated with the Center for Entrepreneurship. Moreover, the Foundation for Enterprise Development (FED) has played an essential role in hosting joint programs with the Center, such as The U.S. Russia Entrepreneurs Exchange, which aims to create a thriving ecosystem of mutually beneficial international entrepreneurship. Both organizations are committed to nurturing a culture of innovation and growth within the entrepreneurial community globally, highlighting their importance in this new partnership.

content_item.parsed_text:
The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- News russian version News Wednesday, June 4, 2003, 3:44 pm  Russian Entrepreneurs Join Their U.S. Counterparts in Peer-Learning Experience San Diego, CA., May 21, 2003 - Recognizing an opportunity for expanded international cooperation and the fact that entrepreneurs learn best from each other, the Foundation for Enterprise Development (FED) and the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE), in partnership with the Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO), are hosting the The U.S. Russia Entrepreneurs Exchange, a peer-learning program that links Russian and American entrepreneurs, from May 29 through June 6, 2003.  The program will take place in five cities across the United States. Six Russian entrepreneurs from fast-growing companies will be matched with U.S.- based business leaders from similar industries. The goal of the Entrepreneurs Exchange is to immerse Russian entrepreneurs in the American entrepreneurial culture, and expose their American hosts to the business culture of Russia. Its a way to build relationships between entrepreneurs within a shared industry sector as a foundation for future business opportunities or trade, said Ray Smilor, president of the Foundation for Enterprise Development. By sharing ideas and strategies, participants can learn from each other and build better, higher performing organizations. The program will bring together industry leaders from varied backgrounds, including food, public relations, finance, television production, manufacturing, and pharmaceuticals and provide them with an intensive hands-on experience in their respective fields. U.S. participants will include Ashley Postlewaite, CEO of Renegade Animation, Inc., a television production company that provides animation for some of the top T.V. shows and commercials; Christopher Rosica, CEO of Rosica Mulhern, Inc., a strategic PR firm based in New York; Joe Polo, CEO of Original Juan, a food production company located in Kansas City, Kansas; Jonathan Slater, CEO of Sequel Management, a venture finance firm in Boston, Massachusetts; James Weldon, CEO of MaxDisplays.com, a manufacturer of flat screen monitors and panels, located in San Jose, California; and  Monique Muri, CEO of Ram Scientific Corp., a medical products company based in Boston, Massachusetts. Russian firms participating include Studio Alisa, a television production company,  CMG, a marketing consulting company,  FIS, a food industry equipment company,  Consoil, a venture finance company, Syscom, an electronic manufacturing company, and Bioform, a medical products company. It became apparent that there was a need for a forum which would allow entrepreneurs to talk to, share ideas with, and get advice from other entrepreneurs across borders, said Victor Sedov, Executive Director of CFE. The most important thing is a collaborative learning process where people are learning from each other. Participants are chosen through a competitive application process and then selected by a joint committee of FED and CFE. The Russian entrepreneurs arrive in Washington, D.C. on May 29 to meet the U.S. participants and then will spend the next nine days with their U.S. host companies located in Boston, New York, Kansas City, Burbank and San Jose. The Foundation for Enterprise Development is a non-profit education, training and consulting organization that advances entrepreneurship worldwide. CFE, located in Moscow, is a catalyst organization, funded by the U.S. Russia Investment Fund and managed by the FED, that advances entrepreneurship in Russia through a combination of education and networking activities. YEO is the premier, peer-to-peer, global community, network and resource for entrepreneurs under age 40. June 4, 2003

U.S.-Russia Entrepreneurs Exchange to Foster International Business Collaboration

Recognizing an opportunity for expanded international cooperation and the fact that entrepreneurs learn best from each other, the Foundation for Enterprise Development (FED) and The Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE), in partnership with the Young Entrepreneurs’ Organization (YEO), are hosting the “The U.S. Russia Entrepreneurs Exchange,” a peer-learning program that links Russian and American entrepreneurs, from May 29 through June 6, 2003. The program will take place in five cities across the United States. Six Russian entrepreneurs from fast-growing companies will be matched with U.S.-based business leaders from similar industries. The goal of the Entrepreneurs Exchange is to immerse Russian entrepreneurs in the American entrepreneurial culture, and expose their American hosts to the business culture of Russia. “It’s a way to build relationships between entrepreneurs within a shared industry sector as a foundation for future business opportunities or trade,” said Ray Smilor, president of the Foundation for Enterprise Development. “By sharing ideas and strategies, participants can learn from each other and build better, higher performing organizations.” The program will bring together industry leaders from varied backgrounds, including food, public relations, finance, television production, manufacturing, and pharmaceuticals, providing them with an intensive hands-on experience in their respective fields. Participants are chosen through a competitive application process and then selected by a joint committee of FED and The Center for Entrepreneurship. The U.S. participants will include Ashley Postlewaite, CEO of Renegade Animation, Inc.; Christopher Rosica, CEO of Rosica Mulhern, Inc.; Joe Polo, CEO of Original Juan; Jonathan Slater, CEO of Sequel Management; James Weldon, CEO of MaxDisplays.com; and Monique Muri, CEO of Ram Scientific Corp.

About Key Organizations

The Foundation for Enterprise Development is a non-profit organization dedicated to advancing entrepreneurship through education, training, and consulting. Established to cultivate entrepreneurial growth worldwide, it supports various initiatives and collaborations aimed at fostering a thriving business ecosystem. The Young Entrepreneurs’ Organization (YEO) is a global network of young business leaders, providing peer-to-peer mentorship, business resources, and networking opportunities. Renowned for its innovative approach to supporting under-40 entrepreneurs, YEO facilitates valuable interactions and learning experiences among its members to drive entrepreneurial success.

content_item.parsed_text:
The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- News russian version News Thursday, July 17, 2003, 4:12 pm  My Business Magazine Announces a new Contest for Entrepreneurs: Business Breakthrough" Business Breakthrough, a contest sponsored by My Business magazine and The U.S.-Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, is open to owners of small and medium-sized Russian companies that have achieved high rates of growth. The objective of the competition is to support entrepreneurial initiative in Russia. According to Dmitry Agarunov, the publisher of My Business magazine, the contest has a dual purpose: First, to generalize the experience of companies that have achieved significant success in their growth. And second, to reveal what enabled these companies to make their breakthrough and achieve outstanding results. This experience is truly invaluable, since Russias business sector is comparatively new and is very much in need of positive examples. To enter the contest, companies must submit an application including the participants registration form and a letter telling about his or her business. The deadline for submission of entries is November 1, 2003 (the participants registration form can be filled out online at www.mybiz.ru ). Entries in the Business Breakthrough contest will be evaluated by a council of experts including prominent businessmen, economists, lawyers, and specialists in management consulting. To qualify for consideration, projects must have been implemented in the Russian market before June 1, 2003 (statistical data on the business may be based on results for 2002). The organizing committee for the contest will select five companies that have demonstrated rapid growth based on effective use of various management tools, including marketing, investment, innovation, finance, and others. The first prize is a two-week internship in a leading U.S. company. Right now were not able to give the details and finer points of the internship program for the winner of the Business Breakthrough contest. After all, we dont know exactly who will win the contest, or exactly what type of business he or she will represent, says Victor Sedov, Executive Director of The U.S.-Russia Center for Entrepreneurship. But I can say with total certainty that we will choose a U.S. company that matches the winners needs and interests as closely as possible. Our American partner--the Young Entrepreneurs' Organization , or YEO--has more than 3000 members in the United States, and each of them owns his or her own business. We can even set up a selection process in order to find a partner that exactly fits the interests of the winning company. Naturally, we will cover all the expenses of the stay in the United States. In addition, owners of firms who are under the age of 40 and whose business turnover is more than US$1 million have an opportunity to receive an invitation to join YEO. For detailed information on the Business Breakthrough contest and how to enter it, go to www.mybiz.ru . General partnerThe US Russia Center for Entrepreneurship. Media partner--E-xecutive Community. Company Information: The U.S.-Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE ) CFE was created in Moscow by the U.S.-Russia Investment Fund. CFEs mission is to meet the needs of owners of rapidly growing companies in the areas of education and networking. CFE conducts seminars, conferences, and roundtables with the participation of entrepreneurs, investors, service providers and policymakers from Russia and abroad. For additional information, contact Victor Sedov, Executive Director of The U.S.-Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, Tel. (095) 252-7927, vsedov@cfe.ru Young Entrepreneurs' Organization (YEO) YEO is the premier, peer-to-peer, global community, network and resource for entrepreneurs.  Since 1987, this international nonprofit educational organization has helped its members build upon their successes through an array of learning and networking opportunities.  With members in more than 142 cities, spanning 35 countries, YEO's rapidly expanding membership includes entrepreneurs from every size and type of business.  YEO membership has increased by some 20 percent last year, and now is nearly 5,000 members strong.  Membership in YEO is by invitation only, and is subject to approval by both YEO International and the sponsoring local chapter.  Prospective YEO members must be under 40 years of age and be a founder, co-founder, owner or controlling shareholder of a business with gross annual revenues exceeding (US) $1 million. E-xecutivean online community of managers E-xecutive is an Internet community designed to bring together top managers in Russia and abroad. The common goal of the community is to achieve success through perfecting professional skills. E - xecutive : · Is the first and foremost active online community, bringing together more than 37,000 top- and mid-level managers. · Is an interactive form of mass media dealing with business topics, in which the communitys members participate, and which has more than 100,000 readers. · Being an E-xecutive member conveys status, the status of a manager who is a recognized professional and a member of an association of successful executives. · For more detailed information, see this website: http://www.e-xecutive.ru Information on My Business magazine My Business is a monthly business magazine focused on ways to build a successful and steadily growing business.  Principal topics - promising markets for business opportunities; the psychology of company management; stories of business success; secrets of competent marketing as exemplified by real business situations; legal and tax consultations; and much more for successful entrepreneurship.  Distributed in Russia and countries of the CIS. Subscription index 44159.  Founder and publisher   the GameLand Publishing House For more information about the magazine, please look on the web site: http://www.mybiz.ru For additional information, contact Olga Zhirkova, PR director of My Business tel. (095) 935-7034, jirkova@gameland.ru back My Business Magazine Media Partner OPORA Russia Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

content_item.parsed_text:
The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- News russian version News Wednesday, August 27, 2003, 10:51 am  The Cream of the Crop in Business - Ernst & Young Begins Entrepreneur of the Year award in Russia The publishing house Kommersant has become a media sponsor of the Entrepreneur of the Year award program, which Ernst & Young, the worlds largest auditing and consulting firm, has conducted annually for 17 years. Now Russian entrepreneurs as well have gained an opportunity to participate in this competition, and this step indicates that business in this country has acquired a deserving reputation in the international arena. The firm of Ernst & Young established the award program for the best entrepreneur in 1986, thus recognizing the growing role of private business as a driver of the global economy and a force that changes our lives for the better. Today the Ernst & Young World Entrepreneur of the Year award program is considered the most prestigious international competition in the field of entrepreneurship, while the award itself ranks as the business worlds equivalent of a Nobel Prize. Seventeen years ago, only businessmen from a few of the United States took part in the first competition. Today the program includes thirty-five countries around the world. The finalists in national competitions vie for the top prize, the Ernst & Young World Entrepreneur of the Year Award, which will be presented in Monte Carlo in May 2004. This year Russia and China joined the contenders for the first time. In both those countries, the holding of the award program is accompanied by heightened attention to the role of business, particularly in connection with future membership in the WTO. Alexander Ivlev, a partner in the firm of Ernst & Young, "Entrepreneurship in Russia already has some history behind it--today there are many private companies in Russia that have been in operation for more than 10 years and are successfully giving concrete form to their ideas and strategies of business development. That has made it possible for us to hold a full-scale Entrepreneur of the Year competition in Russia in conformity with the international standards of Ernst & Young." Gregory Ericksen, a managing director of Ernst & Young, runs the international competition. Support for it is provided by entities such as CNN, CNBC, NASDAQ International, and USA Today. In the various countries involved, the competitions sponsors include the biggest companies and banks: Citigroup, SAP AG, Dell Computer, Société Générale, Deutsche Bank, and others. Equally prestigious is the international panel of judges, selected from well-known entrepreneurs and heads of large companies in various countries throughout the world. For example, in 2001 and 2002 the judges panel for the international competition was headed by John Wall, President of NASDAQ International. It is significant that many winners of past competitions have become international business leaders. They include Jeff Bezos ( Amazon.com ), Michael Dell (Dell Computer Corp.), Pierre Omidyar (eBay Inc.), Howard Schultz (Starbucks Corp.), Scott McNealy (Sun Microsystems), Larissa Herda (Time Warner Telecom), and others. Many of them received the award long before the names of their companies became household words. Today, according to Ernst & Young experts, the average capitalization of the winning company is $22 billion. The NASDAQ Stock Markets list of 100 leaders includes the names of 53 winners of the Entrepreneur of the Year Award. The winner for 2002 was named in Monte Carlo last month: Narayana Murthy, Chairman of the Indian company Infosys Technologies. Participation in the traditional event in Monte Carlo provides not only an opportunity to represent Russia in the global arena and a chance to win the award. The elite of the business world assembles there at a kind of forum, to get to know like-minded persons and exchange ideas for business development. As Alexander Ivlev emphasized, the underlying idea of the competition is to make the worlds best business practices more widely known. In Russia, applications to participate in the competition will be accepted until August 1, 2003, and the winners will be named this November. Among the sponsors of the award program are the management company Yevrazkholding, Renessans Kapital, the agency Mikhaylov and Partners, and the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship . The publishing house Kommersant is the media sponsor of the competition. As for the panel of judges for the Russian national Entrepreneur of the Year award program, its members include Yevgeny Yasin, Director of the Expert Institute, a scientific-charitable fund (NBF); Igor Yurgens, Vice-President of the Russian Union of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs; Yury Isayev, Deputy Minister of Economic Development and Trade of the Russian Federation; Viktor Vereshchagin, Deputy Director of the Expert Institute; Seppo Remes, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the European Business Club in Russia; Andrew Somers, President of the American Chamber of Commerce in Russia; and Victor Sedov, Executive Director of the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship . Alexander Ivlev stressed that representatives of Ernst & Young will not be members of the judging panel at any stage of the competition. After all, clients of the firm may be among the contenders, and besides, the rules of the competition forbid participation by any representatives of the sponsoring companies. Who can compete for the title of Top Entrepreneur of the Year? Those invited to participate are owners or heads of companies who currently have chief responsibility for their operation and who are actively participating in their management. This can also include the head of a state company who holds no share in it but possesses entrepreneurial qualities that are helping him turn it into a competitive participant in the market. Thus the competition is open both to company owners who are leaders of business and to young entrepreneurs. Not only contenders themselves, but also their colleagues, partners, or spouses can make nominations for the award. The criteria for determining the winners will include both quantitative indicators (growth of the companys turnover, increase in profits, and optimal use of human resources) and qualitative factors (innovation in business practices, development of original products, creative solutions in the area of marketing and sales, level of national and international market share). The organizers emphasize that information provided in connection with this competition will be considered strictly confidential and will be accessible only to members of the panel of judges. As Yevgeny Yasin, a member of the judging panel, remarked, this competition is an important event that can heighten the significance of entrepreneurship, raise the self-esteem of Russian entrepreneurs, and increase the entrepreneurs role and responsibility in expanding and developing our countrys economy. Author: Vladimir Gendlin Source: 
			"Kommersant-Dengi", No. 29 (434), July 28, 2003 back My Business Magazine Media Partner OPORA Russia Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

- News russian version News Friday, October 24, 2003, 5:12 pm  Young Entrepreneurs Visit Moscow - Global Business Leaders Attend European Regional Conference Nearly 100 members and guests of the Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO), the premier, peer-to-peer global community, network and resource for entrepreneurs, gathered for a European Regional Conference at the Moscow Marriott Royal Hotel in Moscow, Russia, from 9-12 October, 2003 to attend an international four-day conference. This exclusive event, an annual regional conference for YEO, in partnership with the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship , provided attendees with an opportunity to interact with their entrepreneurial peers and address relevant global issues through a variety of discussions, tours and keynote speaker presentations.  Delegates arrived from from 13 countries including: Russia, Switzerland, France, Germany, Australia, New Zealand, Malaysia, China, Korea, Singapore, India, Canada, and the United States. The program focused on business, cultural and personal growth issues.  A variety of valuable learning opportunities were available throughout this program. The group visited the Star City Space Center, Red Square, the Grand Kremlin Palace, Amber Palace, Tretyakov Gallery, Sergiev Possad, the KGB Museum, and the Bolshoi Theater.  Keynote speakers included:  Sol Gittleman, a global culture expert; and Howard Getson, founder of Capitalogix, a software company that designs expert decision support systems for investment management. Attendees also visited Moscow area businesses and enjoyed Russian cuisine. About YEO The Young Entrepreneurs Organization ( www.yeo.org ) is the premier, peer-to-peer, global community, network and resource for entrepreneurs.  Since 1987, this international nonprofit educational organization has helped its members build upon their successes through an array of learning and networking opportunities.  With members in more than 150 cities, spanning 38 countries, YEO's rapidly expanding membership includes 5,000 entrepreneurs from every size and type of business. Prospective YEO members must be under 40 years of age and be a founder, co-founder, owner or controlling shareholder of a business with gross annual revenues exceeding (US) $1 million.  Members graduate from YEO in the year they turn 40, and are encouraged to then join World Entrepreneurs Organization (WEO). back My Business Magazine Media Partner OPORA Russia Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

This exclusive event, an annual regional conference for YEO, in partnership with The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, provided attendees with an opportunity to interact with their entrepreneurial peers and address relevant global issues through a variety of discussions, tours, and keynote speaker presentations. Delegates arrived from 13 countries, including Switzerland, France, Germany, Australia, New Zealand, Malaysia, China, Korea, Singapore, India, Canada, and the United States. The program focused on business, cultural, and personal growth issues. A variety of valuable learning opportunities were available throughout this program. The group visited notable cultural and business sites and enjoyed local cuisine. Keynote speakers included: Sol Gittleman, a global culture expert; and Howard Getson, founder of Capitalogix, a software company that designs expert decision support systems for investment management. Attendees also visited local area businesses and engaged in diverse activities.

content_item.parsed_text:
The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- News russian version News Monday, October 27, 2003, 5:43 pm  It Takes an Entrepreneur to Teach an Entrepreneur For the first time, the European conference of the Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) will be held in Moscow on October 10  11, 2003.  The president of the organizations Moscow chapter, Mikhail Kupriyanov, discusses the unique opportunities YEO provides its members.  Kupriyanov is co-owner of Syscom 3000. Mikhail Kupriyanov, 36, graduated from the Red Banner Military Institute of the Ministry of Defense in 1989.  After serving in the armed forces, he worked in the telecommunications industry and in the IT business.  Since 2003, he is Director of Business Development for Syscom 3000. --What is YEO, and how is it different from other entrepreneur associations? --This organization is the fastest-growing world-wide organization of entrepreneurs.  It was created by entrepreneurs to foster development, education, and peer support.  To become a member, several criteria must be met.  I will list the most important.  First, you have to be an entrepreneur, not a hired manager (even at the highest level), but a founder, co-founder, key stockholder, owner, or co-owner of a business.  Second, your company has to have an annual turnover of at least $1,000,000.  And third, you must be under the age of 40. Why such restrictions?  Because a companys manager and owner do not have the same psychology.  Also, the threshold for annual turnover determines the degree of a businessmans success  his qualifications, if you will. Personally, I became acquainted with YEO in Paris, at the organizations 2002 European conference.  Right away I understood that it was just what I, as a businessman, needed. --What made such a striking impression on you? --I had been through various phases in business, learned a great deal, and acquired a certain amount of experience.  At some point I realized that I wasnt taking in anything new.  Why?  Well, for example, I wasnt convinced by consultants advice with their focus on theory.  They dont know what it means to run a business on a day-to-day basis.  There was no confidence there. And then we  a few Russian entrepreneurs  found ourselves in the midst of other people like us.  These people were possessors of a certain secret knowledge.  They knew what had to be done and how to do it. --Did you experience their support? --Yes.  We had an opportunity to find answers to virtually any question relating to business practice.  The economic effect of these contacts was colossal.  We heard new ideas, established ties with companies that were interesting business-wise, and got access to YEOs website, with its unique information about business. I felt that it is not right that Russia was excluded from this process.  So, during the trip the Russian delegates formed a Moscow chapter of YEO.  This became possible thanks to the assistance of the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship.  YEO headquarters, which was quite surprised that there was no chapter in Russia, gave all kinds of support.  A decision was made at this time to hold the next European conference in Moscow. Do I need to tell you how important this event is for the country?  It means investment, new contacts, and an invigoration of economic ties. --What in particular is in store at the YEO conference? --The special feature will be the fact that, for many businessmen, this will be their first trip to .  Its absurd, but many truly imagine, if not bears in the streets, then of a mafia rampage along the lines of Chicago in the 1930s.  They are absolutely uninformed about the potential that has developed here. Organizationally, it will not be different from similar events.  Approximately 120 guests from various countries are expected.  The main concept is a traditional one  building bridges between businesses.  I hope the atmosphere will be relaxed and easy.  Many entrepreneurs will come with their families.  At the Paris conference there were even guests with children. --What does YEO give its members, besides peer contacts? --The educational programs, the so-called universities, are extremely useful.  The knowledge you gain with their help (how to launch a new project, how to attract an investor, etc.) is very valuable.  After all, the programs are put on by people who have actual experience of successfully implementing plans, attracting investors, etc.  The universities are held three or four times a year.  For example, this year Russian entrepreneurs attended in Australia. Any member of our organization can ask another member about an issue that concerns him at any time.  Thats the organizations tradition, its way of doing things.  Finding the person you need is easy; you use either the directory or the YEO website.  Admittedly, however, all these sources are for members only  access is granted after you join the organization. As for our Moscow chapter, I can say that contacts are most important.  In half an hour I can learn from a fellow entrepreneur what, in another situation, would take days, if not weeks. Theres another interesting way of working with the organization  forums.  These are events with open communication dealing with topics that may not seem to have direct connection with business.  Business is an extremely special kind of occupation.  At times this results in family problems.  And it can be useful to hear how your peers have solved problems of this kind. There are some taboos here.  Of course, spreading information obtained in the course of a forum is off limits.  And there is a ban on sales  when someone promotes his product or brand.  Incidentally, those two rules of conduct are written down in the YEO regulations.  There is also a ban on giving evaluations and advice.  That has to do with the fact that we recognize the value of each one among us.  A situation where someone says I would have done it this way unintentionally causes a feeling of rejection.  The logical conclusion drawn is that I am smarter than you.  Entrepreneurs are very sensitive about this.  Therefore, when someone shares a problem, they dont expect an evaluation or a piece of advice.  Instead, they listen as their peers talk about their experience in similar situations. What is important is that you stop feeling that you are alone, and that you realize that there are people who have been through similar difficulties and are ready to help you.  Believe me, this is very valuable for an entrepreneur. --How is the Moscow chapter of YEO organized? --Presently, there are eight people in the Moscow chapter.  They all come from different sectors of business: publishing, fast-food products, marketing, and others.  We are open to new members, but we are fairly strict in not chasing after new members.  Quality is far more important than quantity.  Plus, we dont want to ruin the atmosphere of openness and mutual assistance. Therefore, to join YEO you must have the recommendation and approval of member entrepreneurs.  There are dues as well  around $850 a year. You can find out more details about the activities of our organization on our website, www.yeo.org . In general, we try not to formalize our work any more than necessary.  We meet every month and make an effort to divide the meetings into several categories: meetings with important guests, discussions about useful contacts, excursions, and so on.  But nobody comes to our events because they feel they must. --Can such chapters emerge on a regional basis? --Of course. Soon a chapter will open in St. Petersburg.  The entrepreneurs in that city, after seeing our experience, understood that it would be right for them as well. The minimum number of members for a YEO chapter is three.  So, if there is a wish to organize this kind of thing, for example, in the Saratov business community, we are ready to help.  In general, I think that a number of such regional chapters will develop in Russia. --Are the activities of the Moscow chapter of YEO any different from those, say, of the Norwegian chapter? --Certainly. National characteristics can be very clearly traced.  I cant speak for the Norwegians because I simply havent had a lot to do with them.  The Americans, for example, adore informal contacts  like Boy Scout outings, you know.  For example, theyll all go rafting together.  Or, they will all go to somebodys ranch  all in shorts and t-shirts.  We dont do that kind of thing yet.  In general, we become close rather cautiously, gradually.  Probably that is a characteristic of the Russian businessman.  But in one thing we are all the same  we visit each others companies for the purpose of seeing how an unknown business operates.  The benefit these visits provide is appreciable. --What specific actions has the Moscow chapter carried out thus far? --I can mention the one we thought up and carried out jointly with the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship.  Its director, Victor Sedov, helped organize a trip for Russian entrepreneurs to the United States.  There we met with representatives of businesses in the same field as our own.  The trip was short  ten days  but the return it yielded was enormous.  We were struck by the complete openness.  We were able to meet people about whom you read in the newspapers as if they were some kind of celestial beings.  And they talked about the hidden snags in their businesses; about the difficulties encountered at various stages of growth, and literally answered every one of our questions.  The contacts started then are ongoing today. Growth of YEO Membership Year Number of Members 2000 3500 2001 4200 2002 4525 2003 5000 (at present) (Read more about YEO and the Moscow Chapter here .) Author: Alexander Borodulin Source: Svoi Business (My Business), No. 10, October 2003 back My Business Magazine Media Partner OPORA Russia Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
It Takes an Entrepreneur to Teach an Entrepreneur

October 27, 2003

Learn How Entrepreneurs Teach and Support Each Other

The European conference of the Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) was held recently. At the event, Patricia M. Cloherty discussed the unique opportunities YEO provides its members. YEO is the fastest-growing worldwide organization of entrepreneurs, created to foster development, education, and peer support. Membership requires being a founder or co-founder of a business with at least $1,000,000 in annual turnover and being under the age of 40. The organization's aim is to provide valuable on-the-ground experience and peer support, which is often missing from theoretical consultant advice. During conferences, members can share knowledge, establish ties, and access YEO's website for unique business information. The educational programs, or 'universities,' held several times a year, offer insights into launching new projects and attracting investors. Members can ask for help at any time and participate in forums and open communication events on various business-related topics. These initiatives help members feel supported and connected, proving extremely valuable for any entrepreneur.

Key Organizations Making a Difference

Entrepreneurs Organization is a global network that fosters development, education, and peer support among entrepreneurs. Founded in 1987, EO aims to build the world's most influential community of entrepreneurs, offering a support system through mentorship, networking, and educational programs. Their mission is to engage leading entrepreneurs to learn and grow, while maximizing their professional and personal lives. Global Entrepreneurship Week celebrates innovators and job creators launching startups and bringing ideas to life, driving economic growth. It involves activities, competitions, and local and global events to connect entrepreneurs, educators, and policymakers to help them discover new opportunities and create networks of support.
page_cooked.page_title: It Takes an Entrepreneur to Teach an Entrepreneur
page_cooked.page_description: Discover how the Young Entrepreneurs Organization fosters development, education, and peer support for entrepreneurs worldwide. Learn about its unique offerings and how it supports the entrepreneurial community.
page_cooked.page_keywords: Young Entrepreneurs Organization, Entrepreneurship, Business Development, Networking, Business Education

The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- News russian version News Wednesday, November 12, 2003, 6:06 pm  USP Compulink and Delta Capital Management / The US Russia Investment Fund Announce a Major Investment Moscow . November 5, 2003. Delta Capital Management, manager of The US Russia Investment Fund, announced today that it is making a significant investment in USP Compulink. This investment will allow USP Compulink to expand its business to meet the rapidly growing needs of the Russian IT market.  [The Fund is the founder of The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship.] Compulink has been working in the Russia IT market since 1993. In 2002, the company was recognized by the leading analytical agencies as one of the fastest growing IT services companies in Russia. The Russian IT market is expected to grow 27% annually and reach $1.8 billion in 2005. This growth will be fuelled by the need of large Russian industrial companies to leverage IT to increase efficiency of operations; the emergence of rapidly growing medium size companies that must rely on IT systems to manage growth; and the increasing number of foreign companies establishing operations in Russia. Compulink provides a strong mix of system integration and high value-added consulting services. In 2003, Compulinks sales grew by 46% compared to the previous year.   The company maintains a strong client base, including MTS, Kazahtelecom, Promyshlenno-Strahovaya company, and Sberbank. In 2002, the company won a number of the most significant contracts of the "Electronic Russia 2000-2010" program. Compulink will establish itself as a leading national one-stop shop for IT services through a combination of two strategies: strengthening high value-added services (Management Consulting, ERP & CRM) and expanding geographically. Compulink believes it can gain substantial value by combining its brand, experience and scale with the local strengths of regional leaders. Delta Capital Management continues to actively invest in Russias rapidly developing companies. We believe the Russian economy will continue growing and we will have more such opportunities in the near future. Compulink is run by an energetic young management team with significant IT experience. We believe that the Funds investment will help the Company to expand its product offering and to become one of the industrys leaders, says Kirill Dmitriev, Vice President of Delta Capital Management. Director of USP Compulink Mikhail Lyastch adds, This investment will help us realize our long-term strategy, namely to create a multi-service company that is one of the leading one-stop shops for IT services in Russia. He added that this investment will facilitate Compulinks entering the IPO market. In 3 or 4 years, medium size companies will all have the same goal of entering the public markets. It is inevitable. Both the market and the state will benefit from this process. Having a public market for the stock ownership of such small and medium size businesses will result in the formation of a truly strong and independent middle class, which is essential for any democratic state. *** Delta Capital Management Delta Capital Management, manager of The U.S. Russia Investment Fund (the Fund), is a leading Russia-focused private equity fund manager dedicated to identifying and investing in emerging growth companies in Russia. Delta Capital Management focuses mainly, but not exclusively, on three high-growth sectors in Russia fuelled by high consumer demand: financial services, consumer products and services, and TMT (technology, media and telecommunications). Established in 1994, the Fund has invested in excess of $250 mln in 41 portfolio companies and has achieved eight successful exits. For more information, please visit Delta Capital Managements website at www.deltacap.ru . USP Compulink USP Compulink is a full-service IT company. Its business activities include construction of corporate information systems, realization of the projects of ERP and CRM systems application, informational security systems, offering the full complex of services in construction of telecommunication systems and organization of complex equipment delivery in the framework of united projects with their future installation and regional maintenance servicing. The company produces its own computer equipment. Compulink is represented in more than 50 regions of Russia and the CIS. For more information, please visit Compulinks website at www.usp-compulink.ru back My Business Magazine Media Partner OPORA Russia Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
USP Compulink and Delta Capital Management Announce a Major Investment

November 12, 2003

Delta Capital Investment Fuels USP Compulink's Expansion

Delta Capital Management, manager of The US Russia Investment Fund, announced a significant investment in USP Compulink. This investment enables USP Compulink to expand its business to meet the growing needs of the IT market. USP Compulink has been active in the IT market since 1993 and was recognized in 2002 as one of the fastest-growing IT services companies. The IT market is expected to grow significantly, driven by the need for large companies to leverage IT for operational efficiency and the emergence of growing medium-sized companies that require IT systems for management. USP Compulink offers a strong mix of system integration and high value-added consulting services. In 2002, they won significant contracts in the program 'Electronic 2000-2010.' The company aims to become a leading national one-stop shop for IT services through expanding its high value-added services and geographic reach. The investment is also expected to facilitate the company's entry into the IPO market within a few years. This move is anticipated to benefit both market and state, resulting in the formation of a strong middle class.

About Key Organizations Involved

Delta Capital Management, the manager of The US Russia Investment Fund, is a leading private equity fund manager dedicated to investing in emerging growth companies. The firm focuses on high-growth sectors driven by consumer demand, including financial services, consumer products, and technology, media, and telecommunications. Established in 1994, the fund has invested over $250 million in numerous portfolio companies, achieving several successful exits. For more information, visit Delta Capital Management’s website. USP Compulink is a full-service IT company that offers a range of services including the construction of corporate information systems, ERP and CRM system implementation, and the provision of telecommunication system services. The company also produces its own computer equipment and operates in over 50 regions. Compulink aims to combine its brand, experience, and scale with the local strengths of regional leaders to secure substantial value and growth.

content_item.parsed_text:
The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- News russian version News Thursday, February 19, 2004, 5:27 pm  TOP FIVE - Judges of the Business Breakthrough Competition Have Come up with the Top Five Finalists. Judges of the Business Breakthrough competition have come up with the top five finalists. The winner is to be determined by the results of the second round in February. The Business Breakthrough competition, a joint project of our magazine and the US-Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, aims at highlighting the experiences of young and fast-growing Russian companies. The main prize of the competition is a two-week business exchange trip to the United States, where a US counterpart company will be selected in the same industry as the winner. Each participant was awarded points on the basis of a system specifically designed for the competition by the Prado Group.  The five companies that scored the most points reached the second round. Regretfully, some contestants failed to completely fill out the questionnaire and were awarded fewer total points. Alan Abris, General Manager Andrei Kalashnikov The top score, 13.31, was awarded to a Penza-based company, Alan Abris, which manufactures a whole range of industrial products: repair and testing of valves and fittings, packaging, and mobile communication accessories.  The company was founded in 2000.  By 2002 it grew to 150 employees with a turnover of $1.2 million. Its success is a result of several factors.  The company invested in three new production facilities, and the mobile communication accessories business manufactures patent-protected items which are unique in the world.  Also worth mentioning is the fact that Alan Abris started Internet-based sales in Russian regions.  Vadim Samsonov, one of the competitions judges, noted that Alan Abris has become a leader, in spite of the face that it faces difficult challenges, such as implementing flexible manufacturing techniques to meet changing market situations. Lynx ÂCC, General Manager Igor Buchshtab Lynx BCC is a St. Petersburg-based IT company founded in 1997. By 2002, company turnover was $15.7 million with a staff of 69 people.  To Lynx, revenue growth of 187% in 2002 is their greatest achievement. Their score is 12.75 points.  All judges highly appraised Lynx performance, especially noting the complex ideas they turn into reality, and their competitors inability to copy them.  Indeed, some of Lynx technical and technological solutions cannot be copied due to their unique features. Since May 2003, the company has acted as Russia s first UNIX technology Competence Center . RightON, Partner Anna Babynina This Moscow-based company was founded in 1993 (it entered its current line of business in 1999) and offers auditing, evaluation, consultancy and legal services.  With 80 people on staff, it achieved $1.5 million in revenue in 2002. In their opinion, RightONs best achievement is being rating among the top ten Russian auditing and consultancy groups (compiled by Expert advertising agency in 2002).  RightON scored 12.38 points.  Judge Vadim Samsonov was impressed with how they achieved such prominence in such an extremely competitive market where only exclusive or top-quality service can guarantee market share.  However, they did not mention how they managed to achieve this high rating and market share, which did not earn them extra points in this competition.  A little side note: lack of information does not yield dividends, whether in this competition or in business. Pivtorg, Commercial Manager Alexei Kanevsky This Moscow-based company founded in 1996 imports and distributes beer.  They earned $10 million in 2002 and employed 120 staff.  Pivtorg considers their best achievement as being the highest seller of Ochakovo and Baltika beer in the Moscow region.  During the first round of the competition, Pivtorg won 11.9 points.  Judge Viktor Sedov noted that during the companys rapid development in its competitive market, it had to find unusual ways to compete. Kameo, General Manager Anton Kalabin Kameo is based in Moscow.  It was founded in 1997 and is a wholesale distributor of perfumes and cosmetics.  It was founded in 2002 and has a staff of 55 people.  The company scored 11.85 points.  Judges were impressed with Kameos market position and unique marketing solutions that give it a competitive edge in Gillette-branded product sales.  Unfortunately, all judges noted that a lack of corporate information, with some lines of the questionnaire saying data unavailable, prevented Kameo from winning more points. Panel of Judges Alexei Pismarov Strategic Partnership Development Manager, PRADO Group. 9 years business experience.  Created a profitable department from scratch; head of a group of advisers; supervises the Business Growth project. Igor Mann Marketing Director, Alcatel. 11 years business experience.  One of the most respectable market research advisers (Favor Co., Lucent Technologies).  Author of book 100% Marketing. Vadim Samsonov General Manager of consultancy group, Magazin Gotovogo Biznesa (Pret-a-porter Business Shop). 10 years business experience.  A pioneer in the Russian market for buying/selling of SMEs. Viktor Sedov Executive Director of the US-Russia Center for Entrepreneurship. 12 years business experience.  Co-owner of two companies in the .  Director Emeritus, the US-Russia Investment Fund. Source: My Business, #1, January 2004 back My Business Magazine Media Partner OPORA Russia Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

Judges of the Business Breakthrough Competition Have Come up with the Top Five Finalists

February 19, 2004

Top Five Finalists Announced for Business Breakthrough Competition

Judges of the Business Breakthrough competition have come up with the top five finalists. The winner is to be determined by the results of the second round in February. The Business Breakthrough competition, a joint project of our magazine and The Center for Entrepreneurship, aims at highlighting the experiences of young and fast-growing companies. The main prize of the competition is a two-week business exchange trip to the United States, where a US counterpart company will be selected in the same industry as the winner. Each participant was awarded points on the basis of a system specifically designed for the competition by the Prado Group. The five companies that scored the most points reached the second round. Regretfully, some contestants failed to completely fill out the questionnaire and were awarded fewer total points.

More about Key Organizations

Alan Abris, the top-scoring company with 13.31 points, is known for manufacturing a range of industrial products including repair and testing of valves and fittings, packaging, and mobile communication accessories. Founded in 2000, Alan Abris has expanded its operations significantly and reported a turnover of $1.2 million by 2002. Its success is attributed to investments in new production facilities and the development of patent-protected mobile communication accessories, unique globally. Internet-based sales within various regions further contributed to its market leadership. Alan Abris exemplifies how flexible manufacturing techniques can meet changing market situations.

content_item.parsed_text:
The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- News russian version News Tuesday, April 20, 2004, 7:00 pm  MEDIA RELEASE:  Russian Entrepreneurs Rate Their Business Training Needs Entrepreneurs of Mid-Sized Companies in Moscow Participate in a Survey to Rate Their Business Skills and Personal Development Needs Moscow, Russia - Russian entrepreneurs of mid-sized companies rated Strategic Planning the most in-demand business training program, with one-day, peer-to-peer learning the most preferred learning format, according to results of a survey commissioned by the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE).  Included in the study was statistical data that shows how private mid-sized companies contribute to the Moscow economy in terms of wealth generation and job creation.  This report represents one of the few attempts to analyze the state of entrepreneurship in the medium-sized business sector in Russia. This study is important as it destroys the stereotype of Russian entrepreneurs being either small business owners or oligarchs, states Victor Sedov, Executive Director of the U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship.  This research proves what our center has known for a while  that there are a large number of entrepreneurs of dynamic mid-sized companies leading Russias economic revival. In order to obtain an understanding of the business training needs of Russian entrepreneurs, CFE commissioned a first of its kind survey of 112 entrepreneurs of mid-sized companies in Moscow.  The Russian SME Resource Center was commissioned to assist in drafting the questionnaire and managed the survey process and write-up.  The title of the report is:  Tracking the Growth of Entrepreneurship in Russia:  Research on the Business-Training Needs of Entrepreneurs from Private Medium-Sized Companies in Moscow. CFE, which provides educational and network learning events for entrepreneurs of growing companies, undertook this survey to assist it in meeting the specific needs of Russian entrepreneurs.  The questionnaire asked entrepreneurs of companies with annual revenues from $500,000 to $100+ million to rate the factors which influence their businesses development; their business-skills and personal development needs; and their preferred length, form and method of business training.  Responses were then analyzed and compared based upon gender and company revenue.  Official government statistics were also analyzed to determine the extent private mid-sized businesses contribute to the Moscow economy. A short summary of this research can be found on CFEs website ( http://www.cfe.ru/eng/center/?fid=24 ), that of our U.S. partner, the Foundation for Enterprise Development ( www.fed.org ), and the website of the Russian SME Resource Center ( www.rcsme.ru ).  The full report can be purchased from CFE in Russia and FED in the United States. ### The US Russia Center for Entrepreneurship (CFE) is the leading provider of education and network learning activities targeting the needs of growth entrepreneurs in Russia.  CFE serves Russian entrepreneurs to assist them in developing their companies, while facilitating the entrepreneurial process in Russia.  CFE promotes entrepreneurship as a positive force for economic vitality and social advancement by bringing together entrepreneurs with policymakers and investors in a learning environment that supports and advances the role and scope of entrepreneurship in Russia.  CFE is an initiative of the U.S. Russia Investment Fund (Delta Capital Management), a leading private equity fund in Russia, and is managed in cooperation with the Foundation for Enterprise Development. www.cfe.ru ### The Foundation for Enterprise Development is a leading U.S. non-profit education organization dedicated to building high-performing organizations, ensuring economic vitality and enhancing community well-being through entrepreneurship and employee ownership.  The Foundation has extensive experience designing and delivering programs internationally and for a decade has been assisting in educational program development for Russian entrepreneurs. www.fed.org ### The Russian SME Resource Center (RCSME) is a non-commercial foundation initially established under the Tacis program.  The mission of the Russian SME Resource Centre is to provide assistance to private entrepreneurship development in the Russian Federation.  It fulfills its mission by performing research into SME development, and providing policy advisory services and information support to the small and medium-sized business community. www.rcsme.ru back My Business Magazine Media Partner OPORA Russia Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
Entrepreneurs Rate Their Business Training Needs

April 20, 2004, 7:00 pm

Survey Reveals Training Preferences and Needs of Business Owners

Entrepreneurs of mid-sized companies rated Strategic Planning the most in-demand business training program, with one-day, peer-to-peer learning the most preferred learning format. A survey commissioned by the Center for Entrepreneurship revealed that these companies significantly contribute to the economy in terms of wealth generation and job creation. This report helps to analyze the state of entrepreneurship in the medium-sized business sector. This research proves that a large number of dynamic mid-sized companies are leading economic revival. The study surveyed 112 entrepreneurs, each providing insights into their business-skills, personal development needs, and their preferred training formats. The survey included companies with annual revenues ranging from $500,000 to over $100 million. A detailed summary can be found on the websites of the Foundation for Enterprise Development and the Russian SME Resource Center. The full report is available for purchase.

Key Organizations Involved

The Foundation for Enterprise Development is a prominent U.S. non-profit focused on creating high-performing organizations. They enhance community well-being through entrepreneurship and employee ownership. For over a decade, the Foundation has been instrumental in developing educational programs for entrepreneurs, providing extensive experience in international program design and delivery. The Russian SME Resource Center is a non-commercial foundation established under the Tacis program. It supports private entrepreneurship development by conducting SME research, offering policy advisory services, and providing information support to small and medium-sized businesses.

page_cooked.page_description: The Center for Entrepreneurship reveals the training needs of mid-sized company entrepreneurs, highlighting Strategic Planning as the top demand.
page_cooked.page_keywords: entrepreneurs, business training, strategic planning, mid-sized companies, business development, entrepreneurship, personal development

content_item.parsed_text:
The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship 

- News russian version News Tuesday, July 20, 2004, 5:23 pm  Young CEOs hold summit in Moscow Young CEOs from all over the globe gathered in Moscow in October to share their experiences on private entrepreneurship and map out strategies for the future November, 2003 - Moscow temporarily became the center for young business owners and/or CEOs from all over the world in mid-October as two international organizations fostering the cause of businesspeople younger than 40 converged on the Russian capital for a four-day high-level conference dedicated to entrepreneurial issues. The exclusive event  an annual regional conference for over 100 members of the Young Entrepreneurs Organization (YEO) and the World Entrepreneurs Organization (WEO)  was the first of its kind in Eastern and Central Europe since the demise of communism in 1990. Founded in 1987, the YEO and its alumnus the WEO, built on the principle that one learns the most from those who share similar experiences, have grown into a global entrepreneurial community, providing peer-to-peer networking and huge resources dedicated to fostering private entrepreneurship across the globe, the YEO officials said. Brien Biondi, the YEOs CEO for the past seven years, told TRJ that during this period YEO grew from 1,000 to 5,000 members, city and country membership rose from 40 to 140 cities and from six to 35 countries, respectively. Russia is vital to the YEO because it has huge, yet untapped business opportunities, making it a good place to be for the organizations.  Second, Russias membership has made the YEO a bigger, and therefore, a stronger network, he added. The YEO and WEO are a community of peers committed to the development of private entrepreneurship, Biondi said.  And, an entrepreneur is an entrepreneur anywhere, irrespective of his/her location, nationality, religion, political ideologies, race and other factors, he added. Not-a-free-for-all club, the YEO and WEO have stringent membership requirements which ensure only those meeting specific criteria can become YEOers and WEOers, as the organizations select few affectionately call themselves all over the world.  To become members of YEO, Biondi said, potential applicants recommended by current members must be less than 40, founded or co-founded, own or co-own a business or be majority shareholders of companies with gross annual revenues of not less than $1 million.  For the WEO, members are mainly graduates of the YEO, are at least 40 years old and are either owners or majority shareholders in companies with gross annual revenues of at least $7 million, he added. Biondi also spoke highly of the Moscow chapter, which joined the YEO only in February this year. Russian entrepreneurs have been fabulous, he said.  They have been actively engaged in the organizations activities since February.  The knowledge gained in this period has helped them generate new entrepreneurial ideas that have boosted their businesses, created new job opportunities, and improved the economy in general, he added. Victor Sedov, director of the Moscow-based U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship, said membership has boosted entrepreneurial activities among members.  In February, there were just four members in Moscow, but now we have 11.  At this rate, we are on course to hitting our target of enlisting 25 members in 2003, he noted.  For a comparison, France, with a much longer YEO history has just 20, he added. Mikhail Kurpiyanov, president of the YEOs Moscow chapter, also noted their fantastic progress over the past six months.  The fact that this high-level conference is taking place this year in Moscow, the organizations newest and youngest member, also testifies to the rapid growth and deepening co-operation between the chapter and its parent companies. Dmitri Agarunov, director of Gameland, a publishing company, said the atmosphere in the YEO provides a unique moral and psychological support that family members cannot provide. Here, in the organization among peers, one feels he is not alone, he added. Christian Courbois, general director of WestPost, a postal- and courier-services company, said he is currently in talks with the YEO executives to open a branch in St. Petersburg.  We want to establish a chapter because it will give members the opportunities to meet with their business peers and develop business contacts in all YEO member countries, he said. Author: Christopher Kenneth Source: 
			The Russia Journal (¹84) back My Business Magazine Media Partner OPORA Russia (Association of Entrepreneurial Organizations) Copyright © 2002, The U.S. Russia Center for Entrepreneurship Design — Creative Marketing Group , Agency of Internet Technologies ltd Development — Agency of Internet Technologies ltd

page_cooked.page_cooked_html:
Young CEOs Hold Summit in The Center for Entrepreneurship

July 20, 2004

Global Entrepreneurs Converge for Annual Summit

Young CEOs from all over the globe gathered at The Center for Entrepreneurship in October to share their experiences on private entrepreneurship and map out strategies for the future. This exclusive event was an annual regional conference for over 100 members of the Young Entrepreneurs' Organization (YEO) and the World Entrepreneurs' Organization (WEO). The YEO and WEO, founded on the principle that one learns the most from peers, have grown into a global entrepreneurial community, providing peer-to-peer networking and resources dedicated to fostering private entrepreneurship across the globe, according to Brien Biondi, the YEO's CEO. Biondi stated that YEO has grown significantly, with membership increasing from 1,000 to 5,000 over seven years, and country membership rising from six to 35 countries.

Growth and Impact of Entrepreneurial Organizations

The Young Entrepreneurs' Organization (YEO) was founded in 1987 and has since become a cornerstone in global entrepreneurship. Brien Biondi, the YEO's CEO, highlighted Russia's potential as a key component of the organization's growth due to its untapped business opportunities, thus making the organization stronger and more diverse. Membership in YEO requires applicants to be under 40, and they must own or co-own businesses with annual revenues of at least $1 million. The World Entrepreneurs' Organization (WEO) is primarily composed of YEO graduates aged 40 and above, with companies generating at least $7 million in annual revenue. Noteworthy members, such as Brien Biondi and Dmitri Agarunov, emphasize the unique peer support and networking opportunities provided by these organizations, which foster innovation, business growth, and the creation of job opportunities globally.
page_cooked.page_title: Young CEOs Hold Summit in The Center for Entrepreneurship
page_cooked.page_description: Young CEOs from around the globe gathered at The Center for Entrepreneurship, showcasing strategies for fostering private entrepreneurship and contributing to the global economy.
page_cooked.page_keywords: Young CEOs, private entrepreneurship, global entrepreneurial community, Entrepreneurs' Organization, World Entrepreneurs' Organization, entrepreneurship development
